dialogues.speaker: NIGHT SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Series of shots of various streets and buildings in the t of Bedford Falls, somewhere in New York State. The street are deserted, and snow is falling. It is Christmas Eve. O the above scenes we hear voices praying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe everything to George Bailey.  Help him, dear Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph, Jesus and Mary. Help my friend  Mr. Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help my son George tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never thinks about himself, God;  that's why he's in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is a good guy. Give him a  break, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him, dear Lord. Watch over  him tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, God. Something's the matter  with Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please bring Daddy back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS UP from the Bailey home and travels up throu the sky until it is above the falling snow and moving slo toward a firmament full of stars. As the camera stops we  hear the following heavenly voices talking, and as each v is heard, one of the stars twinkles brightly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Joseph, trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like we'll have to send someone  down В– a lot of people are asking  for help for a man named George  Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Bailey. Yes, tonight's his  crucial night. You're right, we'll  have to send someone down immediately.  Whose turn is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I came to see you, sir.  It's that clock-maker's turn again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh В– Clarence. Hasn't got his wings  yet, has he? We've passed him up  right along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, you know, sir, he's got the  I.Q. of a rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but he's got the faith of a  child В– simple. Joseph, send for  Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small star flies in from left of screen and stops. It  twinkles as Clarence speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sent for me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Clarence. A man down on earth  needs our help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid! Is he sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, worse. He's discouraged. At  exactly ten-forty-five PM tonight,  Earth time, that man will be thinking  seriously of throwing away God's  greatest gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear, dear! His life! Then I've  only got an hour to dress. What are  they wearing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will spend that hour getting  acquainted with George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir... If I should accomplish this  mission В– I mean В– might I perhaps  win my wings?  I've been waiting for  over two hundred years now, sir В–  and people are beginning to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that book you've got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence, you do a good job with  George Bailey, and you'll get your  wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, sir. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor George... Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down? What are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're going to help a man, you  want to know something about him,  don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, naturally. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, keep your eyes open. See the  town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stars fade out from the screen, and a light,  indistinguishable blur is seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? I don't see a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot. You haven't got your  wings yet. Now look, I'll help you  out.  Concentrate. Begin to see  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blur on the screen slowly begins to take form. We see group of young boys on top of a snow-covered hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, yes. This is amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ever get your wings, you'll  see all by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group of boys. They are preparing to slide down the hill large shovels. One of them makes the slide and shoots out onto the ice of a frozen river at the bottom of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he slides) Yippee!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your problem, George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him when he was twelve, back  in 1919. Something happens here you'll  have to remember later on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Series of shots as four or five boys make the slide down hill and out onto the ice. As each boy comes down the oth applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Bailey at bottom of slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through megaphone) And here comes the scare-baby, my  kid brother, Harry Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On top of hill, preparing to make his slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Come on, Harry! Attaboy, Harry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry makes his slide very fast. He passes the marks made the other boys, and his shovel takes him onto the thin ic at the bend of the river. The ice breaks, and Harry disap into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George jumps into the water and grabs Harry. As he starts pull him out he yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a chain, gang! A chain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other boys lie flat on the ice, forming a human chain When George reaches the edge with Harry in his arms, they pull them both to safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George saved his brother's life that  day.  But he caught a bad cold which  infected his left ear. Cost him his  hearing in that ear. It was weeks  before he could return to his after- school job at old man Gower's  drugstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five or six boys are coming toward camera, arm in arm,  whistling.  Their attention is drawn to an elaborate  horsedrawn carriage proceeding down the other side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage driving by. We catch a glimpse of an elderly man riding in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys watching the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Potter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that В– a king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Henry F. Potter, the richest  and meanest man in the county.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys continue until they reach Gower's drugstore. The drugstore is old-fashioned and dignified, with jars of co water in the windows and little else. As the kids stop:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Got to work, slave. Hee-haw. Hee- haw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George comes in and crosses to an old-fashioned cigar lig on the counter. He shuts his eyes and makes a wish:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I had a million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks the lighter and the flame springs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George crosses over to the soda fountain, at which Mary H a small girl, is seated, watching him. George goes on to his apron from behind the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling toward back  room) It's me, Mr. Gower. George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gower, the druggist, peering from a window in back ro We see him take a drink from a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George behind soda fountain. He is putting on his apron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet Bick enters the drugstore and sits on one of the s at the fountain. She is the same height as Mary and the s age, but she is infinitely older in her approach to peopl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with warm friendliness) Hello, George. (then, flatly, as she  sees Mary) 'Lo, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (primly) Hello, Violet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George regards the two of them with manly disgust. They a two kids to him, and a nuisance. He starts over for the c counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cents worth of shoelaces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was here first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Violet) Shoelaces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George goes over to the candy counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) I like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like every boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George gives Violet a paper sack containing licorice  shoelaces.  Violet gives him the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the vamp) Help me down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Help you down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet jumps down off her stool and exits. Mary, watching sticks out her tongue as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made up your mind yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George puts some chocolate ice cream in a dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With coconuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like coconuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like coconuts!  Say,  brainless, don't you know where  coconuts come from?  Lookit here В–  from Tahiti В– Fiji Islands, the Coral  Sea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a magazine from his pocket and shows it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new magazine! I never saw it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you never. Only us explorers  can get it. I've been nominated for  membership in the National Geographic  Society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans down to finish scooping out the ice cream, his d ear toward her.  She leans over, speaking softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the ear you can't hear on?  George Bailey, I'll love you till  the day I die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws back quickly and looks down, terrified at what has said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out exploring some day,  you watch. And I'm going to have a  couple of harems, and maybe three or  four wives.  Wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to the cash register, whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in entrance to prescription room at end of fountai Gower comes to the entrance. He is bleary-eyed, unshaven, chewing an old unlit cigar. His manner is gruff and mean. is evident he has been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George! George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not paid to be a canary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to the cash register when he notices an ope telegram on the shelf. He is about to toss it aside when starts to read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads: "We regret to inform you that your son, Robert, died very suddenly this morning of influenza stop. Everyt possible was done for his comfort stop. We await instruct from you.  EDWARD MELLINGTON Pres. HAMMERTON COLLEGE."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOT
dialogues.text: George puts the telegram down. A goodness of heart expres itself in a desire to do something for Gower. He gives th ice cream to Mary without comment and sidles back toward  Gower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gower, drunk, is intent on putting some capsules into a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gower, do you want something...   Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything I can do back here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks curiously at Gower, realizing that he is qui drunk.  Gower fumbles and drops some of the capsules to t floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capsules spilling on floor at their feet.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOT
dialogues.text: George and Gower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get them, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the capsules and puts them in the box. Gower  waves George aside, takes his old wet cigar, shoves it in his mouth and sits in an old Morris chair in the backgrou George turns a bottle around from which Gower has taken t powder for the capsules. Its label reads "POISON." George stands still, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take these capsules over to Mrs.  Blaine's.  She's waiting for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George picks up the capsule box, not knowing what to do o say.  His eyes go, harassed, to the bottle labeled poison George's fingers fumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They have the diphtheria  there, haven't they, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gower stares moodily ahead, sucking his cigar. George tur to him, the box in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a charge, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes В– charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gower, I think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, get going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George comes out into main room. As he puts on his cap he sees a Sweet Caporals ad which says:

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOT
dialogues.text: With an inspiration, George dashes out the door and down street. Mary follows him with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George runs down the street until he comes opposite a two story building with a sign on it reading: "Bailey Buildin and Loan Association." He stops. Potter's carriage is wai at the entrance. Suddenly he runs up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The offices are ancient and a bit on the rickety side. Th is a counter with a grill, something like a bank. Before door marked: "PETER BAILEY, PRIVATE", George's Uncle Billy stands,  obviously trying to hear what is going on inside. He is a very good-humored man of about fifty, in shirt-sleeves. W him at the door, also listening, are Cousin Tilly Bailey, waspish-looking woman, who is the telephone operator, and Cousin Eustace Bailey, the clerk.  The office vibrates wi an aura of crisis as George enters and proceeds directly  toward his father's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy listening at the door. As George is about to  enter his father's office, uncle Billy grabs him by the a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avast, there, Captain Cook! Where  you headin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to see Pop, Uncle Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a squall in there that's  shapin' up into a storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the foregoing, Cousin Tilly has answered the telep and now she calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy... telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank examiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP В– UNCLE BILLY'S LEFT HAND There are pieces of st tied around two of the fingers, obviously to remind him o things he has to do.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOT
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy looking at his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank examiner!  I should have called  him yesterday. Switch it inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters a door marked: "WILLIAM BAILEY, PRIVATE". Georg stands irresolute a moment, aware of crisis in the affair of the Bailey Building and Loan Association, but aware mo keenly of his personal crisis. He opens the door of his  father's office and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's father is seated behind his desk, nervously draw swirls on a pad. He looks tired and worried. He is a gent man in his forties, an idealist, stubborn only for other  people's rights.  Nearby, in a throne-like wheelchair, be which stands the goon who furnishes the motive power, sit Henry F. Potter, his squarish derby hat on his head. The  following dialogue is fast and heated, as though the argu had been in process for some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not crying, Mr. Potter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're begging, and that's a  whole lot worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I'm asking is thirty days more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Pop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, son. (to Potter) Just thirty short days. I'll dig up  that five thousand somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his goon) Shove me up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goon pushes his wheelchair closer to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you put any real pressure on  those people of yours to pay those  mortgages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Times are bad, Mr. Potter. A lot of  these people are out of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then foreclose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that. These families have  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not my children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're somebody's children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you running a business or a  charity ward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Not with my money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Potter, what makes you such a  hardskulled character? You have no  family В– no children. You can't begin  to spend all the money you've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I suppose I should give it to  miserable failures like you and that  idiot brother of yours to spend for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George cannot listen any longer to such libel about his  father. He comes around in front of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a failure! You can't say  that about my father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not! You're the biggest man  in town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes George toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigger'n him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George passes Potter's wheelchair he pushes the old ma shoulder. The goon puts out a restraining hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigger'n everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George proceeds toward the door, with his father's hand o his shoulder. As they go:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gives you an idea of the Baileys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and his father at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him say that about you,  Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, son, thanks. I'll talk to  you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailey closes the door on George and turns back to Potter George stands outside the door with the capsules in his h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gower talking on the telephone. George stands in the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drunkenly) Why, that medicine should have been  there an hour ago. It'll be over in  five minutes, Mrs. Blaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone and turns to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mrs. Blaine's box of capsules?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs George by the shirt and drags him into the back  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capsules...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking him) Did you hear what I said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) Yes, sir, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gower starts hitting George about the head with his open  hands.  George tries to protect himself as best he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of tricks are you playing,  anyway? Why didn't you deliver them  right away? Don't you know that boy's  very sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in tears) You're hurting my sore ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is still seated at the soda fountain. Each time she  hears George being slapped, she winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lazy loafer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Mr. Gower, you don't know what you're  doing. You put something wrong in  those capsules. I know you're unhappy.  You got that telegram, and you're  upset. You put something bad in those  capsules. It wasn't your fault, Mr.  Gower...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George pulls the little box out of his pocket. Gower sava rips it away from him, breathing heavily, staring at the venomously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look and see what you did. Look  at the bottle you took the powder  from. It's poison!  I tell you, it's  poison!  I know you feel bad... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George falters off, cupping his aching ear with a hand. G looks at the large brown bottle which has not been replac on the shelf. He tears open the package, shakes the powde out of one of the capsules, cautiously tastes it, then  abruptly throws the whole mess to the table and turns to  look at George again. The boy is whimpering, hurt, fright Gower steps toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hurt my sore ear again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this time Gower sweeps the boy to him in a hug and,  sobbing hoarsely, crushes the boy in his embrace. George crying too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... No... No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hurt my ear again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Oh, George, George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gower, I won't ever tell anyone.  I know what you're feeling. I won't  ever tell a soul. Hope to die, I  won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late afternoon. A young man is looking over an  assortment of luggage. Across the counter stands Joe Hepn the proprietor of the store В– he is showing a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An overnight bag В– genuine English  cowhide, combination lock, fitted up  with brushes, combs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS CAMERA MOVES UP CLOSER to him, he turns and we get our first glimpse of George as a young man. CAMERA HAS MOVED to a CLOSEUP by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Nope. Nope. Nope. Now, look,  Joe.  Now, look, I... I want a big  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, in action, as George stands with his arms  outstretched in illustration, the picture freezes and bec a still. Over this hold-frame shot we hear the voices fro Heaven:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you stop it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to take a good look at  that face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean the kid that had his  ears slapped back by the druggist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good face. I like it. I like  George Bailey. Tell me, did he ever  tell anyone about the pills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he ever marry the girl? Did he  ever go exploring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arrested CLOSEUP of George springs to life again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big - see!  I don't want one for one  night.  I want something for a  thousand and one nights, with plenty  of room for labels from Italy and  Baghdad, Samarkand... a great big  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see, a flying carpet, huh? I don't  suppose you'd like this old second- hand job, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brings a large suitcase up from under the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're talkin'. Gee whiz, I could  use this as a raft in case the boat  sunk. How much does this cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my trick ear, Joe. It sounded  as if you said no charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating name on  suitcase) That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he sees his name) What's my name doing on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little present from old man Gower.  Came down and picked it out himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiring the bag) He did? Whatta you know about that В–  my old boss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What boat you sailing on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working across on a cattle boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cattle boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he exits) Okay, I like cows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is practically the same except that it is now f of school kids having sodas, etc. A juke box and many lit tables have been added. It has become the hangout of the  local small fry.  There are now three kids jerking sodas. Gower is a different man now В– sober, shaven and good-hu He is behind the counter when George comes in. Gower's fa lights up when he sees George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gower... Mr. Gower... thanks  ever so much for the bag. It's just  exactly what I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George suddenly sees the old cigar lighter on the counter He closes his eyes and makes a wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Oh. Wish I had a million  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he snaps the lighter the flame springs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George shakes Gower's hand vigorously and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN SHOT as George crosses the street, Uncle Billy, cousi Tilly and Cousin Eustace are leaning out of the second fl window of the Building and Loan offices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avast there, Captain Cook. You got  your sea legs yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parlez-vous francais? Hey, send us  some of them picture postcards, will  you, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, George, don't take any plugged  nickels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, George, your suitcase is leaking.   George waves up at them and continues  on across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George crosses the street. He spots Ernie and his cab, and Bert the motor cop, parked alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ernie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie, I'm a rich tourist today. How  about driving me home in style?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert opens the door of the cab and puts George's suitcase inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, your highness, hop in. And,  for the carriage trade, I puts on my  hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George is about to enter the cab, he stops suddenly as sees Violet (now obviously a little sex machine) come tow him. Her walk and figure would stop anybody. She gives hi sultry look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men by the cab, but including Violet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Violet. Hey, you look good.  That's some dress you got on there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reacts to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this old thing? Why, I only wear  it when I don't care how I look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Violet goes by, George and Bert raise their heads abov the top of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Violet's back as she goes. As she crosses the street, elderly man turns to look at her and is almost hit by a c that pulls up with screeching brakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie sticks his head out form the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he enters cab) Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to come along, Bert?  We'll  show you the town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert looks at his watch, then takes another look at Viole retreating figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. Think I'll go home and  see what the wife's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop Bailey is seated at the dinner table. Mrs. Bailey and Annie, the cook, look up toward the vibrating ceiling. Th are SOUNDS of terrific banging and scuffling upstairs. An pounds on the ceiling with a broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) George! Harry! You're shaking the  house down! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let 'em alone. I wish I was up  there with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry'll tear his dinner suit. George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bailey is calling up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why all children should be  girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if they were all girls, there  wouldn't be any... Oh, never mind. (calling upstairs) George! Harry! Come down to dinner  this minute. Everything's getting  cold and you know we've been waiting  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes up the stairs.  Pop is smiling and poking his pl A commotion is heard on the stairs, the boys imitating fa MUSIC. Down they come, holding their mother high between  them on their hands. They bring her into the dining room deposit her gracefully into Pop's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a present for you, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop kisses her. Mother gives Pop a quick hug, then turns  with all the wrath she can muster on the two boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you two idiots! George, sit down  and have dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've eaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, aren't you going to finish  dressing for your graduation party?  Look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. It's George's tux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie crosses the room, holding her broom. Harry reaches for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you lay a hand on me, I'll hit  you with this broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, I'm in love with you. There's  a moon out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he pushes her through the kitchen door, he slaps her f She screams. The noise is cut off by the swinging door. G and his mother sit down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, oh, boy, oh, boy В– my last meal  at the old Bailey boarding house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my lands, my blood pressure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, as he sticks his head through the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, can I have the car? I'm going  to take over a lot of plates and  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What plates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mom В– I'm chairman of the eats  committee and we only need a couple  of dozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no you don't. Harry, now, not my  best Haviland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows Harry into the kitchen, leaving Pop and Georg As she goes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let him have the plates, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and his father, eating at the table. There is a gr similarity and a great understanding between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you have a good trip, George.  Uncle Billy and I are going to miss  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to miss you, too, Pop.  What's the matter? You look tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I had another tussle with Potter  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought when we put him on the  Board of Directors, he'd ease up on  us a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what's eating that old money  grubbing buzzard anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's a sick man. Frustrated and  sick.  Sick in his mind, sick in his  soul, if he has one. Hates everybody  that has anything that he can't have.  Hates us mostly, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room. Harry and his mother come out of the kit Harry carrying a pie in each hand and balancing one on hi head.  CAMERA PANS WITH them as they cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gangway! Gangway! So long, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a match?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny. Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put those things in the car and I'll  get your tie and studs together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mom. You coming later? You  coming later, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, and be bored to  death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't want a better death. Lots  of pretty girls, and we're going to  use that new floor of yours tonight,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No gin tonight, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Pop, just a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, son, not one drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Pop at the table. Annie comes in with some dis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys and girls and music. Why do  they need gin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, did I act like that when I  graduated from high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much. You know, George, wish  we could send Harry to college with  you. Your mother and I talked it  over half the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have that all figured out. You  see, Harry'll take my job at the  Building and Loan, work there four  years, then he'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pretty young for that job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no younger than I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you were born older, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, maybe you were born older. I  suppose you've decided what you're  going to do when you get out of  college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, you know what I've always  talked about В– build things... design  new buildings В– plan modern cities В–  all that stuff I was talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still after that first million before  you're thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll settle for half that in  cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie comes in again from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it's just a hope, but you  wouldn't consider coming back to the  Building and Loan, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie stops serving to hear his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I... (to Annie) Annie, why don't you draw up a chair?   Then you'd be more comfortable and  you could hear everything that's  going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would if I thought I'd hear anything  worth listening to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives George a look, and goes on out into the kitchen Bailey smiles and turns to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's soon to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now, Pop, I couldn't. I couldn't  face being cooped up for the rest of  my life in a shabby little office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, realizing that he has hurt his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Pop. I didn't mean  that remark, but this business of  nickels and dimes and spending all  your life trying to figure out how  to save three cents on a length of  pipe... I'd go crazy. I want to do  something big and something important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You know, George, I feel that in a  small way we are doing something  important.  Satisfying a fundamental  urge. It's deep in the race for a  man to want his own roof and walls  and fireplace, and we're helping him  get those things in our shabby little  office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unhappily) I know, Dad. I wish I felt... But  I've been hoarding pennies like a  miser in order to... Most of my  friends have already finished college.  I just feel like if I don't get away,  I'd bust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Yes... You're right, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see what I mean, don't you, Pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This town is no place for any man  unless he's willing to crawl to  Potter. You've got talent, son. You  get yourself an education. Then get  out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, do you want a shock? I think  you're a great guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To cover his embarrassment, he looks toward the kitchen d and calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, did you hear that, Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie listening through glass in door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard it. About time one of you  lunkheads said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and his father at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to miss old Annie. Pop, I  think I'll get dressed and go over  to Harry's party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good time, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one end of the room an orchestra is playing. George we his way through the dancing couples toward a supper table He and Harry are carrying plates and pies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several of the boys take the plates from him. George look at them, feeling very grown up and out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (introducing George) You know my kid brother, George. I'm  going to put him through college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Wainwright comes in behind Harry, waggles his hands a his ears as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes George. Hello, hee-haw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George swings around, delighted to hear a familiar voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including Sam and Marty Hatch. Sam is assured and breezy, wearing very collegiate clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, oh. Sam Wainwright! How are you?  When did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this afternoon. I thought I'd  give the kids a treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old college graduate now, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah В– old Joe College Wainwright,  they call me. Well, freshman, looks  like you're going to make it after  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam sees Harry and leaves George in the middle of a gestu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry) Harry! You're the guy I want to see.  Coach has heard all about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's followed every game and  his mouth's watering. He wants me to  find out if you're going to come  along with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta make some dough first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you better make it fast. We  need great ends like you В– not broken  down old guys like this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Sam wiggle their fingers at their ears, saluti each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hee-haw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hee-haw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elderly, fussy school principal comes over to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Partridge, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting a pool under this floor was  a great idea. Saved us another  building.  Now, Harry, Sam, have a  lot of fun.  There's lots of stuff  to eat and drink.  Lots of pretty  girls around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet Bick comes into the scene and turns to face George She is waving her dance program at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Violet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, what am I bid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty Hatch enters scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Marty. Well, it's old home  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor, will you, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you remember my kid sister,  Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Momma wants you, Marty." "Momma  wants you, Marty." Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance with her, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... me? Oh, well, I feel funny  enough already, with all these kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on. Be a sport. Just dance  with her one time and you'll give  her the thrill of her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling off) Hey, sis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, excuse me, Violet. Don't be  long, Marty. I don't want to be a  wet nurse for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops suddenly as he sees Mary, staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is standing talking to one of the boys, Freddie, a gl of punch in her hand. For the first time, she is wearing evening gown and she has gained assurance from the admira of the boy with her. She turns around and for the first t she sees George.  For a second she loses her poise, stari at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the next thing I know, some guy  came up and tripped me. That's the  reason why I came in fourth. If it  hadn't been for that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, staring at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that race would have been a cinch.  I tried to find out who it was  later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still staring at George, and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but I couldn't find out. Nobody'd  ever tell you whoever it was because  they'd be scared. They know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Freddie. Marty comes into scene, followed by Geo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what kind of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You remember George? This is Mary.  Well, I'll be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Well... Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, to get back to my story, see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary hands her punch cup to Freddie, and she and George s dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is my dance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, why don't you stop annoying  people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry. Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following George and Mary as they dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. You look at me as if you didn't  know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've passed me on the street almost  every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. That was a little girl named  Mary Hatch. That wasn't you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHISTLE is heard offscreen, and the MUSIC stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry on the orchestra platform, whistle in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oyez В– oyez В– oyez... The big  Charleston contest. The prize? A  genuine loving cup.  Those not tapped  by the judges will remain on the  floor. Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the MUSIC starts and couples begin dancing once more,  they look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay В– what can we lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start their Charleston. We see a SERIES OF SHOTS of  various couples doing their routines, some good, some bad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning against the railing around the dance floor, looki daggers at George. Mickey, a young punk who has had one t many, is beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Othello В– jealous?  Did you know there's a swimming pool  under this floor? And did you know  that button behind you causes this  floor to open up?  And did you further  know that George Bailey is dancing  right over that crack?  And I've got  the key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie needs no more. He takes the key from Mickey and t the switch. The floor begins to part in the middle, each  half sliding under the bleacher seats. Pandemonium starts Dancers begin to scream as they try to get off. Some are engrossed in dancing they continue at top speed. Teachers and elders start to scurry off. As the floor opens, it re an attractive, lighted swimming pool.  George and Mary ar so busy dancing they don't notice the floor opening.  Spotlights concentrate on them. They mistake the screams cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're cheering us. We must be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd watching George and Mary dancing. They move  backwards until finally they reach the edge of the floor fall into the pool below.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: George and Mary still trying to dance in the water В– the crowd on the edge cheering them В– some of the crowd leap into the pool В– the principal trying to restore order, f clasps his hands like a diver and leaps in himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary. The night is warm with a bright moon. Ge is dressed in jersey sweater and oversize football pants  that keep wanting to come down. Mary is in an old white b robe. Each is carrying their wet clothes tied into a bund that leaves a trail of dripping water. As they near the c we hear them singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Buffalo Gals can't you come out  tonight.  Can't you come out tonight.  Can't you come out tonight. Buffalo  Gals can't you come out tonight and  dance by the light of the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot dog! Just like an organ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES WITH them as they proceed down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I told Harry I thought I'd be  bored to death. You should have seen  the commotion in that locker room. I  had to knock down three people to  get this stuff we're wearing here.  Here, let me hold that old wet dress  of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the bundle of clothes from Mary. They stop and l at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look as funny as you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm not quite the football  type.  You... look wonderful. You  know, if it wasn't me talking I'd  say you were the prettiest girl in  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you say it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe I will say it.  How old are you anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen? Why, it was only last year  you were seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too young or too old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Just right. Your age fits  you.  Yes, sir, you look a little  older without your clothes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stops. George, to cover his embarrassment, talks qui on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, without a dress. You look  older...  I mean, younger. You look  just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his confusion George steps on the end of the belt of M bath robe, which is trailing along behind her. She gather the robe around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out her hand) Sir, my train, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pox upon me for a clumsy lout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the belt and throws it over her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your... your caboose, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may kiss my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding her hand, George moves in closer to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey В– hey, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns away from him, singing "Buffalo Gals":

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) As I was lumbering down the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks after her; then picks up a rock from the str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then, I'll throw a rock at the  old Granville house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, don't. I love that old house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a weather-beaten, old-fashioned two-storied house t once was no doubt resplendent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You see, you make a wish and  then try and break some glass. You  got to be a pretty good shot nowadays,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, George, don't. It's full of  romance, that old place. I'd like to  live in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't live in it as a ghost.  Now watch... right on the second  floor there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George hurls the rock at the house. We hear the SOUND of window breaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a grumpy old man in shirt sleeves in a rocking cha on the porch. He looks up as he hears the breaking glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you wish, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not just one wish. A whole  hatful, Mary. I know what I'm going  to do tomorrow and the next day and  the next year and the year after  that. I'm shaking the dust of this  crummy little town off my feet and  I'm going to see the world. Italy,  Greece, the Parthenon, the Colosseum.  Then I'm coming back here and go to  college and see what they know...  and then I'm going to build things.  I'm gonna build air fields.  I'm  gonna build skyscrapers a hundred  stories high. I'm gonna build bridges  a mile long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he talks, Mary has been listening intently. She finall stoops down and picks up a rock, weighting it in her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna throw a rock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old deserted house. Mary throws her rock, and once mo we hear the SOUND of breaking glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's pretty good. What'd you  wish, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at him provocatively, then turns and shuffles down the street, singing as she goes. George hurries afte her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Buffalo Gals, can't you come out  tonight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George joins her in the singing as they proceed down the  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) ...can't you come out tonight, can't  you come out tonight. Buffalo Gals  can't you come out tonight and dance  by the light of the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you wish when you threw that  rock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man on the porch of house, listening to George and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have stopped walking and now face one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told you it might not come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you want, Mary? What do  you want? You want the moon? Just  say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full moon shining through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the word and I'll throw a lasso  around it and pull it down. Hey,  that's a pretty good idea. I'll give  you the moon, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it. And then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then you could swallow it and  it'd all dissolve, see? And the  moonbeams'd shoot out of your fingers  and your toes, and the ends of your  hair. (pauses) Am I talking too much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George finishes talking, he jumps up out of his chair:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!! Why don't you kiss her instead  of talking her to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you kiss her instead of  talking her to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to kiss her, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, youth is wasted on the wrong  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, the man leaves the porch and goes into his  house, slamming the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hold on. Hey, mister, come  on back out here, and I'll show you  some kissing that'll put hair back  on your head. What are you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary runs off scene. George has been once more standing o the belt of her bath robe, so as she goes, her robe comes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops his bundle of clothes and picks up Mary's robe. cannot see her anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I give up. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mary's face peering out from the leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here in the hydrangea bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks toward the bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are. Catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is about to throw her the robe, when a thought strikes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What am I doing? This  is a very interesting situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the bushes) Please give me my robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... A man doesn't get in a  situation like this every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I'd like to have my robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in Bedford Falls, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary thrashes around in the bushes. We hear her say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gesundheit. This requires a little  thought here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting mad) George Bailey! Give me my robe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard about things like this,  but I've never...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Shame on you. I'm going to tell your  mother on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my mother's way up the corner  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) I'll call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're way downtown. They'd be on  my side, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to scream!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Maybe I could sell tickets. Let's  see. No, the point is, in order to  get this robe...  I've got it! I'll  make a deal with you, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlights flash into the scene, and the old Bailey autom drives in, with Harry at the wheel, and Uncle Billy besid him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George! George! Come on home, quick!  Your father's had a stroke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George throws Mary's robe over the bush and gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary... Mary, I'm sorry. I've got to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, George, let's hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Campbell's there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car drives off, Mary, now wearing the robe, rises from the bush and follows the car with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are about twelve directors seated around a long tab They are the substantial citizens of Bedford Falls: Dr.  Campbell, a lawyer, an insurance agent, a real estate  salesman, etc.  Prominently seated among them is Henry F. Potter, his goon beside his wheelchair. Uncle Billy and G are seated among the directors. The Chairman of the Board Dr. Campbell. They have folders and papers before them, o which they have been reporting.  Before each of the direc there are individual reports for them to study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's all we'll need you  for, George. I know you're anxious  to make a train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I have a taxi waiting downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want the Board to know that George  gave up his trip to Europe to help  straighten things out here these  past few months.  Good luck to you  at school, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we come to the real purpose of  this meeting В– to appoint a successor  to our dear friend, Peter Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, I'd like to get to my  real purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait just a minute now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for what?  I claim this  institution is not necessary to this  town. Therefore, Mr. Chairman, I  make a motion to dissolve this  institution and turn its assets and  liabilities over to the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) George, you hear what that buzzard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, it's too soon after  Peter Bailey's death to discuss  chloroforming the Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Bailey died three months ago.  I second Mr. Potter's motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. In that case I'll ask the  two executive officers to withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Campbell rises from his seat. George and Uncle Billy  start to collect their papers and leave the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before you go, I'm sure the whole  board wishes to express its deep  sorrow at the passing of Peter Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was his faith and devotion that  are responsible for this organization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go further than that. I'll say  that to the public Peter Bailey was  the Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at him surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to control  himself) Oh, that's fine, Potter, coming from  you, considering that you probably  drove him to his grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Bailey was not a business man.   That's what killed him. Oh, I don't  mean any disrespect to him, God rest  his soul.  He was a man of high  ideals, so-called, but ideals without  common sense can ruin this town. (picking up papers  from table) Now, you take this loan here to Ernie  Bishop... You know, that fellow that  sits around all day on his brains in  his taxi.  You know... I happen to  know the bank turned down this loan,  but he comes here and we're building  him a house worth five thousand  dollars. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is at the door of the office, holding his coat and papers, ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I handled that, Mr. Potter.  You have all the papers there. His  salary, insurance. I can personally  vouch for his character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) A friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, if you shoot pool with some  employee here, you can come and borrow  money. What does that get us? A  discontented, lazy rabble instead of  a thrifty working class. And all  because a few starry-eyed dreamers  like Peter Bailey stir them up and  fill their heads with a lot of  impossible ideas. Now, I say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George puts down his coat and comes around to the table,  incensed by what Potter is saying about his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute В– just a minute. Now,  hold on, Mr. Potter. You're right  when you say my father was no business  man. I know that. Why he ever started  this cheap, penny-ante Building and  Loan, I'll never know. But neither  you nor anybody else can say anything  against his character, because his  whole life was... Why, in the twenty- five years since he and Uncle Billy  started this thing, he never once  thought of himself. Isn't that right,  Uncle Billy?  He didn't save enough  money to send Harry to school, let  alone me. But he did help a few people  get out of your slums, Mr. Potter.  And what's wrong with that? Why...   Here, you're all businessmen here.  Doesn't it make them better citizens?  Doesn't it make them better customers?  You... you said... What'd you say  just a minute ago?... They had to  wait and save their money before  they even ought to think of a decent  home. Wait! Wait for what? Until  their children grow up and leave  them?  Until they're so old and broken- down that they... Do you know how  long it takes a working man to save  five thousand dollars?  Just remember  this, Mr. Potter, that this rabble  you're talking about... they do most  of the working and paying and living  and dying in this community. Well,  is it too much to have them work and  pay and live and die in a couple of  decent rooms and a bath? Anyway, my  father didn't think so. People were  human beings to him, but to you, a  warped, frustrated old man, they're  cattle. Well, in my book he died a  much richer man than you'll ever be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in your book. I'm  talking about the Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know very well what you're talking  about. You're talking about something  you can't get your fingers on, and  it's galling you. That's what you're  talking about, I know. (to the Board) Well, I've said too much. I... You're  the Board here. You do what you want  with this thing. Just one thing more,  though. This town needs this measly  one-horse institution if only to  have some place where people can  come without crawling to Potter.  Come on, Uncle Billy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George leaves the room, followed by the jubilant Uncle Bi Potter's face is grim with hatred. The "frustrated old ma remark was gall in his veins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sentimental hogwash! I want my  motion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is interrupted by a babble of talk, as the directors t up the argument

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, visibly shaken, is busy with his bag, his papers. is worried about the outcome of the meeting. Dissolving t Building and Loan will alter his plans. Uncle Billy follo him around, chattering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, oh, boy, that was telling him,  George, old boy. You shut his big  mouth. (to Cousin Tilly and  Cousin Eustace) You should have heard him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? We heard a lot of  yelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're being voted out of  business after twenty-five years.  Easy come, easy go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading a newspaper) Here it is, "Help Wanted В– Female."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie is in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still want me to hang around,  George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) Yeah, I'll be right down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you'll miss your train. You're  a week late for school already. Go  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Board  room) I wonder what's going on in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, never mind. Don't worry about  that.  They're putting us out of  business. So what? I can get another  job. I'm only fifty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-six!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on В– go on. Hey, look, you gave  up your boat trip, now you don't  want to miss college too, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Campbell comes running out, all excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George! George! They voted Potter  down!  They want to keep it going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Eustace, Cousin Tilly and Uncle Billy cheer wildly Dr. Campbell and George shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoopee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they've got one condition В– only  one condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the best part of it. They've  appointed George here as executive  secretary to take his father's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! But, Uncle Billy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can keep him on. That's all right.  As secretary you can hire anyone you  like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) Dr. Campbell, now let's get this  thing straight. I'm leaving. I'm  leaving right now. I'm going to  school. This is my last chance. Uncle  Billy here, he's your man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, George, they'll vote with Potter  otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same stars we saw in the opening sequence are once mo twinkling as we hear the voices form Heaven

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I know. He didn't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Not only that, but he  gave his school money to his brother  Harry, and sent him to college. Harry  became a football star В– made second  team All American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but what happened to George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Characteristic activity; a number of people waiting for t train.  Uncle Billy is seated on a baggage wagon eating  peanuts as George paces up and down in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George got four years older, waiting  for Harry to come back and take over  the Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there are plenty of jobs around  for somebody that likes to travel.  Look at this. (takes some folders  from his pocket) There... Venezuela oil fields В–  wanted, man with construction  experience. Here's the Yukon, right  here В– wanted, man with engineering  experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WHISTLE of the approaching train is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thar she blows. You know what the  three most exciting sounds in the  world are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Breakfast is served; lunch  is served; dinner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no! Anchor chains, plane  motors, and train whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peanut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train comes to a stop, and Harry is among the first t get off, followed by an attractive girl about the same ag as he is.  George rushes into the shot, and as the brothe embrace:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joyously) There's the professor now! Old  professor, Phi Beta Kappa Bailey!  All American!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't old George  Geographic Explorer Bailey! What? No  husky dogs? No sled? (to Uncle Billy) Uncle Billy, you haven't changed a  bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody ever changes around here. You  know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, am I glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, where's Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's home cooking the fatted calf.  Come on, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wait. Wait... Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group, including Ruth Dakin. This is the young lady w came off the train with Harry. In the excitement of greet she has been momentarily forgotten. She stands, smiling,  waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth Dakin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth Dakin Bailey, if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Uncle Billy stare, astounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wired you I had a surprise.  Here she is. Meet the wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is thunderstruck. He takes Ruth's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you know В– wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how do you do. Congratulations.   Congratulations. What am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses Ruth.  CAMERA MOVES WITH them down the platform

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, why didn't you tell somebody? (to Ruth) What's a pretty girl like you doing  marrying this two-headed brother of  mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Well, I'll tell you. It's purely  mercenary. My father offered him a  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stops, with a sinking feeling. Uncle Billy and Rut continue out of shot. Harry stops with George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he moves off) Oh, he gets you and a job? Well,  Harry's cup runneth over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George... about that job. Ruth spoke  out of turn. I never said I'd take  it. You've been holding the bag here  for four years, and... well, I won't  let you down, George.  I would like  to... Oh, wait a minute. I forgot  the bags. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out of the shot, George watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George slowly moves after Uncle Billy and Ruth. He is thi deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a surprise to me. This is the  new Mrs. Bailey, my nephew's wife.  Old, old friend of the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. I've heard him speak  of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I want to tell you, we're going  to give the biggest party this town  ever saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES WITH George as he comes into the scene. Ruth detaches herself from the group and offers George some  popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George) Here, have some popcorn. George,  George, George... that's all Harry  ever talks about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Ruth, this... what about this job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, my father owns a glass  factory in Buffalo. He wants to get  Harry started in the research  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a good job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, very. Not much money, but a  good future, you know. Harry's a  genius at research. My father fell  in love with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you did, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth nods, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Eustace is taking a photograph of the family group assembled on the porch. Flash bulbs go off, and the group breaks up. The crowd enters the front door of the house,  leaving George and Uncle Billy on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The latter is tipsy. He feels very high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, boy, oh boy, oh boy. I feel so  good I could spit in Potter's eye. I  think I will. What did you say, huh?  Oh, maybe I'd better go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around for his hat, which is on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my hat? Where's my...
