dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George takes the hat from Uncle Billy's head and hands it him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, George. Which one is  mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) The middle one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, George, old boy, old  boy.  Now, look В– if you'll point me  in the right direction... would you  do that?  George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They descend the porch steps, and George turns his uncle  around and heads him down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Building and Loan pal, huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you just turn this way and go  right straight down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers out of the scene, and as George turns away, w hear Uncle Billy singing "My Wild Irish Rose." There is a CRASH of cans and bottles, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right. I'm all right. "...  the sweetest flower that grows... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is standing at the garden gate. He takes some trav folders from his pocket, looks at them and throws them aw He is obviously disturbed about the latest turn of events His mother comes out of the house and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she kisses him) That's for nothing. How do you like  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods toward the house, where Harry and Ruth, among a  crowd of other couples, are dancing to the MUSIC of a  phonograph, and can be seen through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like she can keep Harry on his  toes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep him out of Bedford Falls, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that Mary Hatch is back  from school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Came back three days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice girl, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind that will help you find the  answers, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, stop that grunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you give me one good reason why  you shouldn't call on Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure В– Sam Wainwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Sam's crazy about Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's not crazy about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how do you know? Did she discuss  it with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, how do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got eyes, haven't I? Why,  she lights up like a firefly whenever  you're around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And besides, Sam Wainwright's away  in New York, and you're here in  Bedford Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all's fair in love and war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (primly) I don't know about war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, you know, I can see right  through you В– right back to your  back collar button... trying to get  rid of me, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. Mrs. Bailey puts George's hat on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's your hat, what's your  hurry?  All right, Mother, old  Building and Loan pal, I think I'll  go out and find a girl and do a little  passionate necking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, if you'll just point me in the  right direction... This direction? (as he leaves) Good night, Mrs. Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is standing in the middle of the street, hands in pockets. As a girl passes, he turns and watches her for a moment.  He is obviously undecided as to what he wants to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet is locking up for the night. A couple of men are  crowding around her, each one bent on taking her out. The is laughter, kidding and pawing. She looks up and sees Ge standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the two men) Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I got a date. But stick  around, fellows, just in case, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll wait for you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH Violet as she crosses the street to Geor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Georgie-Porgie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Vi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks her over. Violet takes her beauty shop seriously and she's an eyeful. She senses the fact that George is f from immune to her attractions. She links her arm in his continues on down the street with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll probably end up down at the  library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop walking and face one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, don't you ever get tired of  just reading about things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are seductive and guileful as she looks up at hi He is silent for a moment, then blurts out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... what are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigned surprise) Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you game, Vi? Let's make a night  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just what she wanted) Oh, I'd love it, Georgie. What'll we  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go out in the fields and take  off our shoes and walk through the  grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we can go up to the falls. It's  beautiful up there in the moonlight,  and there's a green pool up there,  and we can swim in it. Then we can  climb Mt. Bedford, and smell the  pines, and watch the sunrise against  the peaks, and... we'll stay up there  the whole night, and everybody'll be  talking and there'll be a terrific  scandal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) George, have you gone crazy? Walk in  the grass in my bare feet? Why, it's  ten miles up to Mt. Bedford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) You think just because you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time a small crowd has collected to watch the abo scene.  Violet is furious and talking in a loud voice, an George is trying to quiet her. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, just forget about the whole  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George stalks off, the crowd breaks into laughter, and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is walking slowly past the Hatch home. He stares  meditatively at the simple dwelling, then he starts walki ahead.  But after a few steps he turns around and starts  back. He walks past the house a few yards, turns, and sta back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is looking out the window, watching George walk back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, picketing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stops, startled, and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mary. I just happened to be  passing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so I noticed. Have you made up  your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you made up your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About coming in. Your mother just  phoned and said you were on your way  over to pay me a visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks surprised at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother just called you? Well, how  did she know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't tell anybody. I just went  for a walk and happened to be passing  by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mary has disappeared from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) What do you... went for a walk, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is running down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling off) I'll be downstairs, mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks in a mirror at the bottom of the stairs and fi her hair. She is plainly excited at George's visit. She r into the parlor and puts a sketch on an easel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a caricature of George throwing a lasso around the  moon.  Lettering on the drawing says: "George Lassos The  Moon."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOT
dialogues.text: Mary runs into the hall, opens the phonograph and puts on record of "Buffalo Gals."  Then she opens the front door stands there waiting for George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is struggling with the gate В– he finally kicks it open and starts slowly up the path toward Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, are you coming in or aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll come in for a minute, but  I didn't tell anybody I was coming  over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and George are in the entrance hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you get back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get that dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. I thought you'd go  back to New York like Sam and Ingie,  and the rest of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I worked there for a couple of  vacations, but I don't know... I  guess I was homesick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Homesick? For Bedford Falls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and my family and... oh,  everything.  Would you like to sit  down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go through the doorway into the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, for a minute. I still  can't understand it though. You know  I didn't tell anybody I was coming  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you rather leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want to be rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sees the cartoon on the easel and bends down for a close look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating cartoon) Some joke, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary sitting on the divan. He is uncomfortable and she tries desperately to keep the conversation alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I see it still smells like  pine needles in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence for a moment, then Mary joins in singing with the phonograph record which has been playing all thr the above scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) "And dance by the light..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Oh, yeah... yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his watch, as though about to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately) It was nice about your brother Harry,  and Ruth, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... yeah, yeah. That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course I like her. She's a  peach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's just marriage in general  you're not enthusiastic about, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, marriage is all right for Harry,  and Marty, and Sam and you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hatch, in a bathrobe, and with her hair in curlers, leaning over the banister as she calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary! Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary seated on the divan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's down there with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's George Bailey, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Bailey? What's he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (to George) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant) Me? Not a thing. I just came in to  get warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to mother) He's making violent love to me,  Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell him to go right back home,  and don't you leave the house, either.  Sam Wainwright promised to call you  from New York tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heatedly) But your mother needn't... you know  I didn't come here to... to... to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) What did you come here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. You tell me. You're  supposed to be the one that has all  the answers.  You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terribly hurt) Oh, why don't you go home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost shouting) That's where I'm going. I don't know  why I came here in the first place!  Good night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George leaves the room, the telephone in the hall star ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George) Good night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary! Mary! The telephone! It's Sam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost weeping) I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary comes into the hall, she stops by the phonograph, which is still playing "Buffalo Gals," takes off the reco with a jerk, and smashes it against the machine. The phon is still ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, he's waiting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary picks up the phone, George comes in from the fron porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot my hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overly enthusiastic) Hee-haw! Hello, Sam, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, great. Gee, it's good to hear  your voice again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George has stopped, hat in hand, to hear the first greeti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that's awfully sweet of  you, Sam. (glances toward door,  sees George still  there) There's an old friend of yours here.   George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean old moss-back George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, old moss-back George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hee-haw! Put him on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I'll call him. (calling) George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't want to speak to George,  you idiot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does so. He asked for him. (calling) Geo... George, Sam wants to speak to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands the instrument to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is seated at his desk, while a couple of his friends nearby, with highballs in their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Well, George Baileyoffski! Hey, a  fine pal you are. What're you trying  to do? Steal my girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) What do you mean? Nobody's trying to  steal your girl. Here... here's Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait a minute. Wait a minute. I  want to talk to both of you. Tell  Mary to get on the extension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Here. You take it. You tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother's on the extension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she hears this, she hastily hangs up the extension pho on which she has been listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can both hear. Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary takes the telephone from George and holds it so that necessity George's cheek is almost against hers. He is ve conscious of her proximity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) We're listening, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a big deal coming up that's  going to make us all rich. George,  you remember that night in Martini's  bar when you told me you read  someplace about making plastics out  of soybeans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Yeah-yeah-yeah... soybeans.  Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Dad's snapped up the idea.  He's going to build a factory outside  of Rochester. How do you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is watching George interestedly. George is very cons of her, close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester? Well, why Rochester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why not? Can you think of  anything better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know... why not right  here?  You remember that old tool  and machinery works? You tell your  father he can get that for a song.  And all the labor he wants, too.  Half the town was thrown out of work  when they closed down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That so? Well, I'll tell him. Hey,  that sounds great! Oh, baby, I knew  you'd come through. Now, here's the  point. Mary, Mary, you're in on this  too. Now listen.  Have you got any  money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money? Yeah... well, a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now listen. I want you to put  every cent you've got into our stock,  you hear?  And George, I may have a  job for you; that is, unless you're  still married to that broken-down  Building and Loan. This is the biggest  thing since radio, and I'm letting  you in on the ground floor. Oh,  Mary...  Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you tell that guy I'm giving  him the chance of a lifetime, you  hear? The chance of a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary listens, she turns to look at George, her lips al on his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) He says it's the chance of a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George can stand it no longer. He drops the phone with a  crash, grabs Mary by the shoulders and shakes her. Mary b to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Now you listen to me! I don't want  any plastics! I don't want any ground  floors, and I don't want to get  married В– ever В– to anyone! You  understand that? I want to do what I  want to do. And you're... and  you're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her to him in a fierce embrace. Two meant for ea other find themselves in tearful ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mary... Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George... George... George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hatch is at the top of the stairs. She practically f at what she sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Tilly's face fills the screen as she cries:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK, and we hear the SOUND of the Wedding M People are crowded into the rooms: family, friends, neigh There is a din of conversation. Mary and George appear at the top of the stairs in traveling clothes, with Mrs. Hat red-eyed, behind them. Mary throws her bouquet, which is  caught by Violet Bick. As they come out onto the porch, w see that it is raining.  Nevertheless, Cousin Eustace has his camera equipment set up and is taking pictures of the group. George and Mary dodge through the rain and a showe of rice and get into Ernie's taxicab, which pulls away fr the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bailey and Annie, the maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Harry, now George. Annie, we're  just two old maids now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak for yourself, Mrs. B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary are in each other's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If either of you two see a stranger  around here, it's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look! Somebody's driving this  cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie reaches over and hands George a bottle of champagne done up in gift wrappings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, the cop, sent this over. He  said to float away to Happy Land on  the bubbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look at this. Champagne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, where are you two going  on this here now honeymoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going? (takes out a fat roll  of bills) Look at this. There's the kitty,  Ernie.  Here, come on, count it,  Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like a bootlegger's wife. (holding up the money) Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what we're going to do?  We're going to shoot the works. A  whole week in New York. A whole week  in Bermuda. The highest hotels В– the  oldest champagne В– the richest caviar  В– the hottest music, and the prettiest  wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it! Then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Then what, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that, who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it В– come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab passes the bank, and Ernie sees a crowd of people around the door. He stops the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scurrying people under umbrellas, swarming around the ban doors.  Panic is in the air. Attendants are trying to clo down. Several people come running past the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look now, but there's something  funny going on over there at the  bank, George, I've never really seen  one, but that's got all the earmarks  of a run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ernie, if you got any money in  the bank, you better hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, let's not stop. Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George gets out of the cab and looks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, dear. Oh-oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, let's not stop, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back in a minute, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George runs off up the street, toward the Building and Lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An iron grill blocks the street entrance to the Building Loan.  It has been locked. A crowd of men and women are  waiting around the grill. They are simply-dressed people, whom their savings are a matter of life and death.  Georg comes in with an assumed cheerful manner. The people look him silently, half shamefaced, but grimly determined on t rights. In their hearts there is panic and fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, everybody. Mrs. Thompson, how  are you? Charlie? What's the matter  here, can't you get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one answers. He quickly unlocks the grill door and pus it open. Followed by the crowd, George runs upstairs and  into the outer offices of the Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, followed by the still-silent people, comes in. Un Billy is standing in the doorway to his private office, t a drink from a bottle. He motions to George to join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Uncle Billy? A holiday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to George's office. George turns back cheerfull to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in, everybody. That's right,  just come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George vaults over the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, why don't you all sit down.   There are a lot of seats over there.  Just make yourselves at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, can I see you a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people ignore George and remain standing in front of teller's window. They all have their passbooks out. Georg hurries into his office where Uncle Billy is waiting for  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just did, but they said you left.  This is a pickle, George, this is a  pickle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right now, what happened? How  did it start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does anything like this ever  start?  All I know is the bank called  our loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About an hour ago. I had to hand  over all our cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every cent of it, and it still was  less than we owe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy mackerel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I got scared, George, and  closed the doors. I... I... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole town's gone crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone rings. Uncle Billy picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, hello? George... it's Potter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter seated behind his desk, his goon alongside him.  Standing in front of the desk is a distinguished-looking  man, obviously the president of the bank. He is mopping h brow with his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, there is a rumor around town  that you've closed your doors. Is  that true?  Oh, well, I'm very glad  to hear that...  George, are you all  right? Do you need any police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Police? What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, mobs get pretty ugly sometimes,  you know. George, I'm going all out  to help in this crisis. I've just  guaranteed the bank sufficient funds  to meet their needs.  They'll close  up for a week, and then reopen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Uncle Billy) He just took over the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may lose a fortune, but I'm willing  to guarantee your people too. Just  tell them to bring their shares over  here and I will pay them fifty cents  on the dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously) Aw, you never miss a trick, do you,  Potter? Well, you're going to miss  this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George bangs the receiver down and turns to meet Uncle Bi anxious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you close your doors before six  P.M. you will never reopen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He realizes George has hung up, and clicks the phone  furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, was it a nice wedding? Gosh,  I wanted to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... (looks at string on  Uncle Billy's finger) ...you can take this one off now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ominous SOUND of angry voices comes from the other roo George and Uncle Billy exit from George's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More people have crowded around the counter. Their mutter stops and they stand silent and grim. There is panic in t faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, just remember that this thing  isn't as black as it appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George speaks, sirens are heard passing in the street  below.  The crowd turn to the windows, then back to Georg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some news for you, folks.  I've just talked to old man Potter,  and he's guaranteed cash payments at  the bank. The bank's going to reopen  next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, George, I got my money here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he guarantee this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, Charlie. I didn't even ask  him.  We don't need Potter over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Ernie have come into the room during this scene. Mary stands watching silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take mine now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but you... you... you're thinking  of this place all wrong. As if I had  the money back in a safe. The money's  not here. Your money's in Joe's  house... (to one of the men) ...right next to yours. And in the  Kennedy house, and Mrs. Macklin's  house, and a hundred others. Why,  you're lending them the money to  build, and then, they're going to  pay it back to you as best they can.  Now what are you going to do?   Foreclose on them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got two hundred and forty-two  dollars in here, and two hundred and  forty-two dollars isn't going to  break anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a slip) Okay, Tom. All right. Here you are.  You sign this. You'll get your money  in sixty days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now that's what you agreed to  when you bought your shares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a commotion at the outer doors. A man (Randall)  comes in and makes his way up to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom... Tom, did you get your money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I did. Old man Potter'll pay  fifty cents on the dollar for every  share you got. (shows bills)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Fifty cents on the dollar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, cash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George) Well, what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Tom, you have to stick to your  original agreement. Now give us sixty  days on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Randall) Okay, Randall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to go to Potter's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better to get half than nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few other people start for the door.  CAMERA PANS WITH  George as he vaults over the counter quickly, speaking to the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom! Tom! Randall! Now wait... now  listen... now listen to me. I beg of  you not to do this thing. If Potter  gets hold of this Building and Loan  there'll never be another decent  house built in this town. He's already  got charge of the bank.  He's got  the bus line. He's got the department  stores. And now he's after us.  Why?  Well, it's very simple. Because we're  cutting in on his business, that's  why.  And because he wants to keep  you living in his slums and paying  the kind of rent he decides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people are still trying to get out, but some of them  have stood still, listening to him. George has begun to m an impression on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, you lived in one of his houses,  didn't you? Well, have you forgotten?  Have you forgotten what he charged  you for that broken-down shack? (to Ed) Here, Ed. You know, you remember  last year when things weren't going  so well, and you couldn't make your  payments. You didn't lose your house,  did you? Do you think Potter would  have let you keep it? (turns to address the  room again) Can't you understand what's happening  here? Don't you see what's happening?   Potter isn't selling. Potter's buying!   And why? Because we're panicky and  he's not.  That's why. He's picking  up some bargains.  Now, we can get  through this thing all right. We've  got to stick together, though. We've  got to have faith in each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my husband hasn't worked in over  a year, and I need money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I going to live until the  bank opens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got doctor bills to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't feed my kids on faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this scene Mary has come up behind the counter.  Suddenly, as the people once more start moving toward the door, she holds up a roll of bills and calls out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George jumps over the counter and takes the money from Ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I got two thousand dollars!  Here's two thousand dollars. This'll  tide us over until the bank reopen. (to Tom) All right, Tom, how much do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doggedly) Two hundred and forty-two dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) Aw, Tom, just enough to tide you  over till the bank reopens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take two hundred and forty-two  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George starts rapidly to count out the money. Tom throws passbook on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll close my account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your account's still here. That's a  loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns and slips out through the crowd, followed by E George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars to Tom and speaks to Ed, the next in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. All right, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got three hundred dollars here,  George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy takes out his wallet and takes out all the ca he's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, now, Ed... what'll it take till  the bank reopens? What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose twenty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty dollars. Now you're talking.  Fine.  Thanks, Ed. (to Mrs. Thompson,  next in line) All right, now, Mrs. Thompson. How  much do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's your own money, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind about that. How much do  you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get along with twenty, all  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting it out) Twenty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll sign a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to sign anything. I  know you'll pay it back when you  can. That's okay. (to woman next in  line) All right, Mrs. Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I have seventeen-fifty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven... (he kisses her) Bless your heart, Of course you can  have it. You got fifty cents? (counting) Seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Uncle Billy and Cousin Tilly are behind the count watching the minute hand of a clock on the wall as George counts off the seconds. Cousin Eustace is ready to close door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) We're going to make it, George.  They'll never close us up today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting) Six... five... four... three... two...   one... Bingo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Eustace slams and locks the door, and scurries aro the counter to join the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made it! Look... (holds up two bills) ... look, we're still in business!  We've still got two bucks left!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy is taking a drink out of his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's have some of that. Get  some glasses, Cousin Tilly. (to Uncle Billy) We're a couple of financial wizards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those Rockefellers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a tray for these great big  important simoleons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll save them for seed. A toast!   They raise their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast! A toast to Papa Dollar and  to Mama Dollar, and if you want the  old Building and Loan to stay in  business, you better have a family  real quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish they were rabbits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish they were too. Okay, let's  put them in the safe and see what  happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them parade through the office; George puts t two dollars in the safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George comes out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing out cigars) Wedding cigars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Oh-oh... wedding! Holy mackerel, I'm  married! Where's Mary? Mary... (he runs around looking  for her) Poor Mary. Look, I've got a train to  catch. (looks at his watch) Well, the train's gone. I wonder if  Ernie's still here with his taxicab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George rushes into his office to look out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on telephone) George, there's a call for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, will you get my wife on the  phone?  She's probably over at her  mother's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bailey is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want Mrs. Bailey. I want my  wife.  Mrs. Bailey! Oh, that's my  wife! Here, I'll take it in here. (picks up phone) Mary? Hello. Listen, dear, I'm  sorry...  What? Come home? What home?  Three-twenty Sycamore? Well, what...  whose home is that? The Waldorf Hotel,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old-fashioned, run-down house, unpainted and warped by the weather. It once had class but has not been lived in years.  This is the house that George and Mary will live from now on.  The rain is pouring down. A faint glow of l shines out from bottom windows. George hurries into scene He stops to make sure it is the right number before going the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert and man working in rain, sorting through travel post

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is the company's posters,  and the company won't like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to get a ticket  next week? Haven't you any romance  in you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I have, but I got rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading poster) Liver pills! Who wants to see liver  pills on their honeymoon? What? They  want romantic places, beautiful  places...  places George wants to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sharp whistle is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie is leaning from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bert, here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we got to get this up. He's  coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The groom, idiot. Come on, get that  ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) What are they В– ducks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert and the man are putting up travel posters to cover u the broken windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that ladder up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right В– all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up... hurry up... hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hurrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is approaching the front door of the house, on whi a sign is hanging: "Bridal Suite." Ernie looks out throug the curtain covering the broken glass of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya... Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie opens the door, revealing himself as a homemade but This has been accomplished by rolling up his pants and pu on an old coachman's hat. George enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entray, monsieur, entray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is carpetless, empty В– the rain and wind cause funny noises upstairs. A huge fire is burning in the  fireplace. Near the fireplace a collection of packing box are heaped together in the shape of a small table and cov with a checkered oil cloth. It is set for two. A bucket w ice and a champagne bottle sit on the table as well as a  bowl of caviar. Two small chickens are impaled on a spit  over the fire. A phonograph is playing on a box, and a st from the phonograph is turning the chickens on the spit. phonograph is playing "Song of the Islands." Mary is stan near the fireplace looking as pretty as any bride ever lo She is smiling at George, who has been slowly taking in t whole set-up. Through a door he sees the end of a cheap b over the back of which is a pair of pajamas and a nightie Ernie exits and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears in her eyes) Welcome home, Mr. Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overcome) Well, I'll be... Mary, Mary, where  did you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rush into each other's arms and hold each other in  ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert and Ernie, standing in the pouring rain, start singi "I Love You Truly."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They remain embraced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the night we broke the  windows in this old house? This is  what I wished for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, you're wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finish their song, and Ernie kisses Bert on the fore Bert slams Ernie's hat on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of one of the miserable shacks that line the str are two vehicles. One of them is George Bailey's rickety  car, and the other is an even more rickety truck piled hi with household goods. The Martini family is moving. The f consists of Martini, his wife and four kid of various age from two to ten.  George and Mary are helping the Martini move. About a dozen neighbors crowd around. Martini and  George, assisted by three of the Martini children, are  carrying out the last of the furniture.  As they emerge f the house, one of the neighbors, Schultz, calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martini, you rented a new house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rent? (to George) You hear what he say, Mr. Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I own the house. Me, Giuseppe Martini.  I own my own house. No more we live  like pigs in thisa Potter's Field.  Hurry, Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... (to Mary) Bring the baby. (to Martini) I'll bring the kids in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Mr. Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary gets in the front seat of the car, with the baby in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, kids В– here В– get in here.  Now get right up on the seat there.   Get the...  get the goat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family goat gets in the back seat with the three kids

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, everybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rickety caravan starts off down the street, to the ch of the neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign hanging from a tree "Welcome to Bailey Park." CAMERA PANS TO follow George's car and the old truck laden with  furniture as they pass В– we hear Martini's voice singing Sole Mio." Bailey Park is a district of new small houses, not all alike, but each individual. New lawns here and th and young trees. It has the promise when built up of bein pleasant little middle class section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary are on the porch of the new house, with t Martinis lined up before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Martini, welcome home.   The Martinis cross themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Wainwright is standing in front of his big black town car. Sam is the epitome of successful, up-and-coming  businessman. His wife, in the car, is a very attractive,  sophisticated-looking lady, dripping with furs and jewels Sam is watching George across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That old George... he's always making  a speech. (to George) Hee-haw! (wiggles his hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Sam Wainwright!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, who cares. (to Mrs. Martini,  giving her loaf of  bread) Bread! That this house may never  know hunger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Martini crosses herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving her salt) Salt! That life may always have  flavor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing bottle to  Martini) And wine!  That joy and prosperity  may reign forever. Enter the Martini  castle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Martinis cross themselves, shaking hands all around. kids enter, with screams of delight. Mrs. Martini kisses  Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter seated in his wheelchair at his desk, with his goo beside him.  His rent collector, Reineman, is talking,  pointing to maps spread out on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Potter, it's no skin off  my nose. I'm just your little rent  collector.  But you can't laugh off  this Bailey Park any more. Look at  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buzzer is heard, and Potter snaps on the dictaphone on desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman Blatz is here to see  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to dictaphone) Oh, tell the congressman to wait. (to Reineman) Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen years ago, a half-dozen houses  stuck here and there. (indicating map) There's the old cemetery, squirrels,  buttercups, daisies. Used to hunt  rabbits there myself. Look at it  today. Dozens of the prettiest little  homes you ever saw.  Ninety per cent  owned by suckers who used to pay  rent to you. Your Potter's Field, my  dear Mr. Employer, is becoming just  that. And are the local yokels making  with those David and Goliath  wisecracks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they are, are they? Even though  they know the Baileys haven't made a  dime out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know very well why. The Baileys  were all chumps. Every one of these  homes is worth twice what it cost  the Building and Loan to build. If I  were you, Mr. Potter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Well, you are not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he leaves) As I say, it's no skin off my nose.  But one of these days this bright  young man is going to be asking George  Bailey for a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reineman exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bailey family has been a boil on  my neck long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips the switch on the dictaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary are talking to Sam Wainwright in front of the latter's car. Hs wife, Jane, is now out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just stopped in town to take a  look at the new factory, and then  we're going to drive on down to  Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you have your friends join  us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, sure. Hey, why don't you kids  drive down with us, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm afraid I couldn't get away,  Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still got the nose to the old  grindstone, eh? Jane, I offered to  let George in on the ground floor in  plastics, and he turned me down cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now, don't rub it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not rubbing it in. Well, I guess  we better run along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is handshaking all around as Sam and Jane get into  their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awfully glad to have met you, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, George. See you in the funny  papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for dropping around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to chauffeur) To Florida! (to George) Hee-haw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hee-haw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big black limousine glides away, leaving George stand with his arm around Mary, gazing broodingly after it. The slowly walk over to George's old car and look at it silen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter is lighting a big cigar which he has just given Ge The goon is beside Potter's chair, as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Quite a cigar, Mr.  Potter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it? I'll send you a box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Well, I... I suppose I'll find out  sooner or later, but just what exactly  did you want to see me about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) George, now that's just what I like  so much about you. (pleasantly and  smoothly) George, I'm an old man, and most  people hate me. But I don't like  them either, so that makes it all  even. You know just as well as I do  that I run practically everything in  this town but the Bailey Building  and Loan. You know, also, that for a  number of years I've been trying to  get control of it... or kill it. But  I haven't been able to do it. You  have been stopping me. In fact, you  have beaten me, George, and as anyone  in this county can tell you, that  takes some doing. Take during the  depression, for instance. You and I  were the only ones that kept our  heads. You saved the Building and  Loan, and I saved all the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Well, most people say you stole  all the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The envious ones say that, George,  the suckers. Now, I have stated my  side very frankly. Now, let's look  at your side.  Young man, twenty- seven, twenty-eight...  married,  making, say... forty a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) Forty-five!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five. Forty-five. Out of which,  after supporting your mother, and  paying your bills, you're able to  keep, say, ten, if you skimp. A child  or two comes along, and you won't  even be able to save the ten. Now,  if this young man of twenty-eight  was a common, ordinary yokel, I'd  say he was doing fine. But George  Bailey is not a common, ordinary  yokel. He's an intelligent, smart,  ambitious young man В— who hates his  job В– who hates the Building and  Loan almost as much as I do. A young  man who's been dying to get out on  his own ever since he was born. A  young man... the smartest one of the  crowd, mind you, a young man who has  to sit by and watch his friends go  places, because he's trapped.  Yes,  sir, trapped into frittering his  life away playing nursemaid to a lot  of garlic-eaters.  Do I paint a  correct picture, or do I exaggerate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mystified) Now what's your point, Mr. Potter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My point? My point is, I want to  hire you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) Hire me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to manage my affairs, run  my properties. George, I'll start  you out at twenty thousand dollars a  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George drops his cigar on his lap. He nervously brushes o the sparks from his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flabbergasted) Twenty thou... twenty thousand dollars  a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't mind living in the nicest  house in town, buying your wife a  lot of fine clothes, a couple of  business trips to New York a year,  maybe once in a while Europe. You  wouldn't mind that, would you, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I? (looking around  skeptically) You're not talking to somebody else  around here, are you? You know, this  is me, you remember me? George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, George Bailey. Whose ship  has just come in В– providing he has  brains enough to climb aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what about the Building and  Loan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, confound it, man, are you afraid  of success? I'm offering you a three  year contract at twenty thousand  dollars a year, starting today. Is  it a deal or isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Potter, I... I... I know I  ought to jump at the chance, but  I... I just...  I wonder if it would  be possible for you to give me twenty- four hours to think it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, sure. You go on home and  talk about it to your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, I'll draw up the  papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offers hand) Okay, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand) Okay, Mr. Potter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they shake hands, George feels a physical revulsion.  Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him. In that  moment of physical contact he knows he could never be  associated with this man.  George drops his hand with a  shudder. He peers intently into Potter's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vehemently) No... no... no... no, now wait a  minute, here!  I don't have to talk  to anybody!  I know right now, and  the answer is no! NO!  Doggone it! (getting madder all  the time) You sit around here and you spin  your little webs and you think the  whole world revolves around you and  your money. Well, it doesn't, Mr.  Potter!  In the... in the whole vast  configuration of things, I'd say you  were nothing but a scurvy little  spider. You...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and shouts at the goon, impassive as ever beside Potter's wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And that goes for you too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George opens the office door to exit, he shouts at Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it goes for you too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is modestly furnished with just a cheap bed, a c or two, and a dresser. Mary is asleep in the bed. As Geor comes in, his head is filled with many confusing thoughts relating to incidents in his past life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't mind living in the nicest  house in town. Buying your wife a  lot of fine clothes, going to New  York on a business trip a couple of  times a year.  Maybe to Europe once  in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George takes off his hat and coat, moves over to the dres and stares at his reflection in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm going to do tomorrow  and the next day and next year and  the year after that. I'm shaking the  dust of this crummy little town off  my feet, and I'm going to see the  world... And I'm going to build  things. I'm going to build air fields.   I'm going to build skyscrapers a  hundred stories high. I'm going to  build a bridge a mile long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the above thoughts are passing through George's hea his attention is caught by a picture on the wall near the dresser:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the sketch of George lassoing the moon that we firs saw in Mary's living room. The lettering reads: "George L The Moon."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you want, Mary? You want  the moon? If you do, just say the  word; I'll throw a lasso around it  and pull it down for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is now awake, and starts singing their theme song:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Buffalo Gals, won't you come out  tonight, won't you come out tonight,  won't you come out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George crosses over and sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Hatch, why in the world did you  ever marry a guy like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To keep from being an old maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have married Sam Wainwright  or anybody else in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to marry anybody else  in town. I want my baby to look like  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't even have a honeymoon. I  promised you... (does a double take) ...Your what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously) You mean... Mary, you on the nest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Bailey lassos stork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lassos the stork! You mean you...  What is it, a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary nods her head happily.

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Over the following SERIES OF SHOTS we hear the voices of  Joseph and Clarence in Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is crossing the street, heading for the offices of the Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you've probably already guessed  that George never leaves Bedford  Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary had her baby, a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sitting on the floor playing with a baby. A little b is in a playpen nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she had another one В– a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is busy hanging wallpaper and painting the old place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day after day she worked away remaking  the old Granville house into a home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George has just come into the hall. He is obviously tired and discouraged as he starts up the stairs. The knob on t banister comes off in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night after night George came back  late from the office. Potter was  bearing down hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of men, obviously just drafted, marching along in camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then came a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms busily  sewing, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma Bailey and Mrs. Hatch joined the  Red Cross and sewed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, with portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee an doughnuts to men leaning from the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary had two more babies, but still  found time to run the U.S.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Wainwright showing set of blueprints to two Army offi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Wainwright made a fortune in  plastic hoods for planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which sev men are seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter became head of the draft board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from papers) One-A... One-A... One-A...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from th top of an Army tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gower and Uncle Billy sold war bonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, in uniform, moving cautiously with fixed bayonet. S and flashes of gunfire in background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert the cop was wounded in North  Africa.  Got the Silver Star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of planes, flying overhead, with parachutes drop from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie, the taxi driver, parachuted  into France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty in the foreground, beckoning to soldiers to come on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty helped capture the Remagen  Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes. He w as he exits through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry... Harry Bailey topped them  all. A Navy flier, he shot down  fifteen planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flaming plane crashes into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...two of them as they were about to  crash into a transport full of  soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, behind the counter, is trying to quiet a crowd of people all clamoring for more ration points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George? Four-F on account of his  ear, George fought the battle of  Bedford Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George shouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on... hold on... hold on now.  Don't you know there's a war on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, in the uniform of an air raid warden, is patrolli his beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air raid Warden...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man beside lighted window pulls down the shade as George  blows his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is helping load his old car with scrap paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...paper drives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheelbarrow full of junk being dumped onto pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Scrap drives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Rubber drives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like everybody else, on V-E Day he  wept and prayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On V-J Day he wept and prayed again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph, now show him what happened  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is walking along the sidewalk reading a newspaper. is a raw, gusty day, and his overcoat and muffler flap in the breeze.  Draped around one arm is a large Christmas  wreath. Under his other arm are several more copies of th paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning, day before Christmas,  about ten A.M. Bedford Falls time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George comes to where Ernie, the taxi driver, is standing the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out paper) Hi, Ernie, look at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front page of the paper, the Bedford Falls Sentinel. headline reads: "PRESIDENT DECORATES HARRY BAILEY В– LOCA BOY WINS CONGRESSIONAL MEDAL OF HONOR". The subhead tells a plan for a giant jubilee and parade, to be followed by banquet, in honor of Commander Harry Bailey, U.S.N. on hi way home from Washington after receiving the Congressiona Medal of Honor. There's a large picture of President Trum pinning the coveted medal on Harry's bosom, in the midst dignitaries; a picture of the transport which Harry saved Practically the whole front page is devoted to the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding) Gonna snow again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged) What do you mean В– it's gonna snow  again?  Look at the headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know В– I know В– I know. I think  it's marvelous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gower comes running across the street from his drugstore joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Commander Harry Bailey. Mr. Gower,  look at this В– the second page. (gives them papers) Now look, this is for you. This is  for you, this is for you. (as he leaves) See you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy is walking along the street, humming happily himself. He sees some men decorating the Court House with banners and bunting В– there is a huge sign reading: "Wel Home Harry Bailey"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) Be sure you spell the name right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The offices are unchanged, still small-time and old-fashi The same office force, albeit a few years older: Cousin T and Cousin Eustace. Seated on a chair is a middle-aged ma with a brief case. The outer door opens and George enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extra! Extra! Read all about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Tilly and Cousin Eustace are talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George! George! It's Harry now on  long distance from Washington!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry! What do you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reversed the charges. It's okay,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean it's okay?  For a  hero? (takes the phone) Harry!  Oh, you old seven kinds of a  son of a gun. Congratulations!  How's  Mother standing it?... She did? What  do you know... (to Eustace) Mother had lunch with the President's  wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait till Martha hears about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they have to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) What did they have to eat? Harry,  you should see what they're cooking  up in the town for you... Oh, are  they? (to Eustace) The Navy's going to fly Mother home  this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Uncle Billy? (to Eustace) Has Uncle Billy come in yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he stopped at the bank first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) He's not here right now, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Eustace has turned away from George and caught a  glimpse of the man waiting in the chair. This is Carter, bank examiner, come for his annual audit of the books of Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) But look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) ...now tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) ...George, that man's here again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Bank... bank examiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... (on phone) Talk to Eustace a minute, will you.  I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the phone to Eustace, puts down his wreath and g over to Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carter В– bank examiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Carter, Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all excited around here. (shows him paper) My brother just got the Congressional  Medal of Honor. The President just  decorated him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess they do those things.  Well, I trust you had a good year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good year? Well, between you and me,  Mr. Carter, we're broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (leading him into  office) ...now, come right in here, Mr.  Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go) Although I shouldn't wonder when you  okay reverse charges on personal  long distance calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, shall we hang up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. He wants to talk to Uncle  Billy.  You just hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in doorway) Now, if you'll cooperate, I'd like  to finish with you by tonight. I  want to spend Christmas in Elmira  with my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you at all, Mr. Carter,  Just step right in here. We'll fix  you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy is filling out a deposit slip at one of the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing) December twenty-fourth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a thick envelope from his inside pocket and thum through the bills it contains. It is evidently a large su of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight thousand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter is being wheeled in by his goon. Various bank offi run over to greet him В– he is reading a newspaper. Uncle Billy has finished filling out his slip, and comes over t taunt Potter, the envelope containing the money in his ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good morning, Mr. Potter. What's  the news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the paper from Potter's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well, Harry Bailey wins  Congressional Medal. That couldn't  be one of the Bailey boys? You just  can't keep those Baileys down, now,  can you, Mr. Potter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does slacker George feel about  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very jealous, very jealous. He only  lost three buttons off his vest. Of  course, slacker George would have  gotten two of those medals if he had  gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy folds Potter's paper over the envelope contai his money, and flings his final taunt at the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, Potter, some people like  George had to stay home. Not every  heel was in Germany and Japan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a cold rage, Potter grabs his paper and wheels off tow his office. Uncle Billy smiles triumphantly and goes towa deposit window with his deposit slip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy and bank teller at the  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still chuckling) Good morning, Horace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy hands the bank book over. The teller opens it starts to punch it with rubber stamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you forgot something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, aren't you going to make a  deposit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then... it's usually customary  to bring the money with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shucks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy searches through every pocket he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks bewildered) I know I had...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teller, knowing the old man's vagaries, points to one the numerous string tied around his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about that one there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm? Well, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter is now behind his desk. He spreads the newspaper o in front of him, muttering as he does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees the envelope, looks inside at the money. Then, to his goon, indicating the office door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me back there. Hurry up. (as they go) Come on, look sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter opens the door just a little, and peers through in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy looks around for the money envelope. It is no there.  He looks puzzled, thinks hard, then a look of con creeps into his eyes. He starts thumping his pockets, wit increasing panic, and looks in the waste paper basket on floor. He finally rushes through the door and out into th street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to goon) Take me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The goon wheels him back to his desk. He is deep in thoug with a crafty expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy running across the street in the direction of the Building and Loan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George coming from room where he has just left the bank  examiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just make yourself at home, Mr.  Carter.  I'll get those books for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Violet Bick standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Vi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, can I see you for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, of course you can. Come on in  the office here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears a noise, and sees Uncle Billy entering the offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy, talk to Harry. He's on  the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Violet enter his private office. Uncle Billy c hurrying in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, Uncle Billy, hurry. Long  distance, Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, here's Harry on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, your nephew, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Here he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy picks up the phone and speaks distractedly,  without knowing what he is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
