dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello... hello... Yes, Harry В– yes...   everything... everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up agitatedly, muttering to himself as he goes i his own office. Cousin Tilly and Cousin Eustace look afte him, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have my head examined. Eight  thousand dollars. It's got to be  somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George has just finished writing something, and is slippi the paper into an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands it to her) Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Character? If I had any character,  I'd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a lot of character to leave  your home town and start all over  again.  He pulls some money from his  pocket, and offers it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, George, don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, now, you're broke, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to do, hock your  furs, and that hat? Want to walk to  New York?  You know, they charge for  meals and rent up there just the  same as they do in Bedford Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking money) Yeah В– sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a loan. That's my business.  Building and Loan. Besides, you'll  get a job. Good luck to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, then says a strange thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad I know you, George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches up and kisses him on the cheek, leaving lipst George opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George and Violet come through the door, they are bein watched by Cousin Tilly, Cousin Eustace and the bank exam who is still waiting to go to work on the books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hello to New York for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah В– yeah... sure I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let's hear from you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet sees the lipstick on George's cheek, and dabs at i with her handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Merry Christmas,  Vi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bailey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Carter, I'm sorry. I'll be  right with you. (to Cousin Tilly) Uncle Billy in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George opens the door he sees Uncle Billy frantically  looking for the missing envelope. The office is in a mess drawers are opened, and papers scattered on the floor and the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unc... What's going on? The bank  examiner's here, and I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in dismay) He's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. He wants the accounts  payable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stops short, suddenly aware of the tragic old eyes looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy gestures nervously for George to come in. He  does so and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Tilly is at her switchboard, and Cousin Eustace  standing beside her. Carter is still waiting in the doorw to his office.  Suddenly the door opens and George comes  striding out. He goes directly to the safe and starts  searching, but doesn't find the money. Then he goes to th cash drawer in the counter, and looks through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eustace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Eustace runs over to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Uncle Billy with any  cash last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had it on his desk counting it  before he closed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy and George are retracing the former's steps  through the snow, looking everywhere for the missing mone They pause for a moment on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, did you buy anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Not even a stick of gum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. All right. Now we'll go  over every step you took since you  left the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue on down the street on their search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter is peering through the slats of the Venetian blind watching them as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Uncle Billy continue their search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shabby, old-fashioned, gas-lit room which has been turn almost inside out and upside down in an effort to locate missing money. Drawers of an old secretary have been pull out and are on the floor. Every conceivable place which m have been used by Uncle Billy to put the money has been  searched. George, his hair rumpled, is feverishly pursuin the search. Uncle Billy is seated behind the desk, his he on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you put the envelope in your  pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... yeah... maybe... maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Maybe В– maybe! I don't want any maybe.   Uncle Billy, we've got to find that  money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (piteously) I'm no good to you, George. I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. Do you have any secret  hiding place here in the house?  Someplace you could have put it?  Someplace to hide the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhausted) I've been over the whole house, even  in rooms that have been locked ever  since I lost Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy starts sobbing hysterically. George grabs him the lapels and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) Listen to me! Listen to me! Think!  Think!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) I can't think any more, George. I  can't think any more. It hurts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George jerks him to his feet and shakes him. Uncle Billy  stands before him like a frisked criminal, all his pocket hanging out, empty. George's eyes and manner are almost  maniacal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming at him) Where's that money, you stupid, silly  old fool? Where's the money?  Do you  realize what this means? It means  bankruptcy and scandal, and prison!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws Uncle Billy down into his chair, and still shou at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it means! One of us is  going to jail! Well, it's not going  to be me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George turns and heads for the door, kicking viciously at waste basket on the floor as he goes. Uncle Billy remains sobbing at the table, his head in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie (aged eight) is seated at the piano playing "Hark, Herald Angels Sing," which she practices during the remai of this scene. There is a Christmas tree all decorated ne the fireplace. At a large table Mary is busy putting  cellophane bows and decorations on gift packages. At a sm table Pete (aged nine) is seated with pad and pencil in t throes of composition.  On the floor Tommy (aged three) i playing with a toy vacuum cleaner. We hear the SOUND of a door open and close. Mary turns and sees George enter the hall, a slight powdering of snow on his head and shoulder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George comes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Daddy, hello daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating tree) How do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sneezes violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring the wreath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring the Christmas wreath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What wreath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Merry Christmas wreath for the  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruffly) No. I left it at the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it snowing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your coat and hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left them at the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stares at him, aware that something unusual has happ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Nothing's the matter. Everything's  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George slumps into an armchair and lifts Tommy onto his l Mary is helping Pete decorate the Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Pete, you're a big boy.  You  can put the star up. Way up at the  top. That's it.  Fill in that little  bare spot right there.  That's it. (to George) Isn't it wonderful about Harry?   We're famous, George. I'll bet I had  fifty calls today about the parade,  the banquet. Your mother's so excited,  she...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this scene, George has been sitting in the chair,  hugging Tommy to him, and crying quietly. Mary realizes t something is seriously wrong, and breaks off. Janie is  thumping away at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must she keep playing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) I have to practice for the party  tonight, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy says we can stay up till  midnight and sing Christmas carols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you sing, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George) Better hurry and shave. The families  will be here soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising from chair) Families!  I don't want the families  over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary leads him out toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on out in the kitchen with me  while I finish dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit with Tommy hanging onto George's coat-tails, an pulling at him. CAMERA PANS WITH them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go toward kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a hectic day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Oh, yeah, another big red letter day  for the Baileys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, the Browns next door have a  new car. You should see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns on him) Well, what's the matter with our  car?  Isn't it good enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tugging at coat) Excuse me, excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Excuse you for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I burped!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, darling, you're excused.  Now go upstairs and see what little  Zuzu wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy leaves, and Mary turns to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu! What's the matter with Zuzu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she's got a cold. She's in bed.  Caught it coming home from school.   They gave her a flower for a prize  and she didn't want to crush it so  she didn't button up her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, a sore throat or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a cold. The doctor says it's  nothing serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor? Was the doctor here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I called him right away. He  says it's nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she running a temperature? What  is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a teensie one В– ninety-nine,  six.  She'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George paces about the kitchen, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, it's this old house. I don't  know why we don't all have pneumonia.  This drafty old barn! Might as well  be living in a refrigerator. Why did  we have to live here in the first  place and stay around this measly,  crummy old town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) George, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong? Everything's wrong! You call  this a happy family? Why did we have  to have all these kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming in) Dad, how do you spell "frankincense"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) I don't know. Ask your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George goes toward doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where're you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going up to see Zuzu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear his footsteps as he leaves. Mary looks after him, puzzled and concerned, then comes over to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me to write a play for  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F-R-A-N-K-I-N...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knob on the banister comes off in his hand, and for a moment he has an impulse to hurl it into the living room. Then, he replaces the knob, and goes on up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of Janie at the piano can be heard, the same  monotonous rhythm over and over. Zuzu (aged six) is sitti up in her bed, the lamp burning beside her. She is holdin her prize flower.  George tiptoes in. Then, as he sees sh awake, he comes over, sitting on the edge of her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won a flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to get out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait now. Where do you think you're  going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to give my flower a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. Here, give  Daddy the flower. I'll give it a  drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head and presses the flower to her. A few  petals fall off. She picks them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Daddy... paste it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, all right. Now, I'll paste  this together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him the fallen petals and the flower. He turns back to Zuzu, pretending to be tinkering with the flower. sticks the fallen petals in his watch pocket, rearranges flower, and then turns back to Zuzu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is, good as new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give the flower a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George puts the flower in a glass of water on the table b her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, will you do something for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you try to get some sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sleepy. I want to look at my  flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know В– I know, but you just go to  sleep, and then you can dream about  it, and it'll be a whole garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes her eyes and relaxes on the bed. George pulls covers over her. He bends down and his lips touch a tendr of the child's hair. Then he gets up and tiptoes out of t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie is still pounding with grim determination at the pi Pete is seated at the table writing. Tommy is playing wit his toy vacuum cleaner. The telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes in and picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. (on phone) Hello. Yes, this is Mrs. Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George enters shot, and stands listening to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Mrs. Welch. I'm sure  she'll be all right. The doctor says  that she ought to be out of bed in  time to have her Christmas dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Zuzu's teacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hand over receiver) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snatches the phone from Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello. Hello, Mrs. Welch?  This is  George Bailey. I'm Zuzu's father.  Say, what kind of a teacher are you  anyway?  What do you mean sending  her home like that, halfnaked?  Do  you realize she'll probably end up  with pneumonia on account of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts a restraining hand on his arm. He shakes it off. She cannot know that George's tirade against Mrs. Welch i really a tirade against the world, against life itself,  against God. Over the phone we hear Mrs. Welch's voice  sputtering with protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the sort of thing we pay  taxes for В– to have teachers like  you? Silly, stupid, careless people  who send our kids home without any  clothes on? You know, maybe my kids  aren't the best-dressed kids; maybe  they don't have any decent clothes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary succeeds in wresting the phone from George's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, that stupid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary speaks quickly in to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Welch. I want to  apologize...  hello... hello... (to George) She's hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) I'll hang her up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the telephone is suddenly alive with a powerful male  voice calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George hears this and grabs the receiver from Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Wait a minute. (on phone) Hello? Who is this? Oh, Mr. Welch?   Okay, that's fine, Mr. Welch. Gives  me a chance to tell you what I really  think of your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary once more tries to take the phone from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raving at her) Will you get out and let me handle  this? (into phone В– shouting) Hello? Hello? What? Oh, you will,  huh?  Okay, Mr. Welch, any time you  think you're man enough... Hello?  Any...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before he can think of an insult to top Welch's, we h a click on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the receiver, and turns toward the living roo His face is flushed and wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, how do you spell "Hallelujah"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) How should I know? What do you think  I am, a dictionary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yells at Tommy, noisily playing with his vacuum cleane

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, stop that! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie is still practicing at the piano, monotonously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) Janie, haven't you learned that silly  tune yet? You've played it over and  over again.  Now stop it! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has suddenly become ominously quiet, the only SO being George's labored breathing. George goes over to a c of the room where his workshop is set up В– a drawing tab several models of modern buildings, bridges, etc. Savagel he kicks over the models, picks up some books and hurls t into the corner.  Mary and the children watch, horrified. George looks around and sees them staring at him as if he were some unknown wild animal.  The three children are cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping for breath) I'm sorry, Mary, Janie. I'm sorry. I  didn't mean... you go on and practice.   Pete, I owe you an apology, too. I'm  sorry. What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding back his  tears) Nothing, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and the children stare at him, stunned by his furiou outburst. There is silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with everybody?  Janie, go on. I told you to practice. (shouts) Now, go on, play!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie breaks into sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an outburst) George, why must you torture the  children?  Why don't you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight of Mary and the children suffering is too much George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around him, then quickly goes out the front door the house. Mary goes to the phone, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedford, two-four-seven, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Daddy in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I pray for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Janie, pray very hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Tommy. (on phone) Hello, Uncle Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter is seated at his desk, his goon beside him. He is  signing some papers. George is seated in a chair before t desk, without a hat or coat, covered lightly with snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in trouble, Mr. Potter. I need  help.  Through some sort of an  accident my company's short in their  accounts. The bank examiner's up  there today. I've got to raise eight  thousand dollars immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) Oh, so that's what the reporters  wanted to talk to you about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) The reporters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They called me up from your  Building and Loan. Oh, there's a man  over there from the D.A.'s office,  too. He's looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) Please help me, Mr. Potter. Help me,  won't you please? Can't you see what  it means to my family? I'll pay you  any sort of a bonus on the loan...  any interest. If you still want the  Building and Loan, why I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) George, could it possibly be there's  a slight discrepancy in the books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. There's nothing wrong with  the books. I've just misplaced eight  thousand dollars. I can't find it  anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) You misplaced eight thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you notified the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. I didn't want the publicity.   Harry's homecoming tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorts) They're going to believe that one.  What've you been doing, George?  Playing the market with the company's  money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. No, sir. I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it В– a woman, then? You know,  it's all over town that you've been  giving money to Violet Bick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that it makes any difference to  me, but why did you come to me? Why  don't you go to Sam Wainwright and  ask him for the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get hold of him. He's in  Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what about all your other  friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have that kind of money,  Mr. Potter. You know that. You're  the only one in town that can help  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. I've suddenly become quite  important. What kind of security  would I have, George? Have you got  any stocks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonds? Real estate? Collateral of  any kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls out policy) I have some life insurance, a fifteen  thousand dollar policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... how much is your equity in  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Look at you. You used to be so cocky!  You were going to go out and conquer  the world! You once called me a  warped, frustrated old man. What are  you but a warped, frustrated young  man? A miserable little clerk crawling  in here on your hands and knees and  begging for help. No securities В– no  stocks В– no bonds В– nothing but a  miserable little five hundred dollar  equity in a life insurance policy.  You're worth more dead than alive.   Why don't you go to the riff-raff  you love so much and ask them to let  you have eight thousand dollar? You  know why? Because they'd run you out  of town on a rail... But I'll tell  you what I'm going to do for you,  George. Since the state examiner is  still here, as a stockholder of the  Building and Loan, I'm going to swear  out a warrant for your arrest.   Misappropriation of funds В–  manipulation В– malfeasance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George turns and starts out of the office as Potter picks the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, George, go ahead. You  can't hide in a little town like  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is out of the door by now.  CAMERA MOVES CLOSER to Potter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Bill? This is Potter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George comes out of the bank into the falling snow. He cr the street, tugs at the door of his old car, finally step over the door, and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attractive little roadside tavern, with the name  "Martini's" in neon lights on the front wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is an Italian restaurant with bar. The bottles  sparkle.  There are Christmas greens and holly decorating the place. It has a warm, welcoming spirit, like Martini  himself, who is welcoming new arrivals. The booths and th checkered-cloth-covered tables are full. There is an air festivity and friendliness, and more like a party than a  public drinking place. George is seated at the bar В– he had a great deal to drink, far more than he's accustomed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (greeting new customers) Merry Christmas. Glad you came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about some of that good spaghetti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, CAMERA MOVES CLOSER to George. Nick, the  bartender, is watching him solicitously. Seated on the ot side of George is a burly individual, drinking a glass of beer. George is mumbling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God... God... Dear Father in Heaven,  I'm not a praying man, but if you're  up there and you can hear me, show  me the way. I'm at the end of my  rope. Show me the way, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly) Are you all right, George? Want  someone to take you home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George shakes his head. Martini comes over to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) Why you drink so much, my friend?  Please go home, Mr. Bailey. This is  Christmas Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ugly man next to George, who has been listening, reac sharply to the name "Bailey."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailey? Which Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without any warning, the burly man throws a vicious punch George, who goes down and out. Martini, Nick and several  others rush to pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George) And the next time you talk to my  wife like that you'll get worse. She  cried for an hour. It isn't enough  she slaves teaching your stupid kids  how to read and write, and you have  to bawl her out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) You get out of here, Mr. Welch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Welch reaches in his pocket for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait... I want to pay for my  drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind the money. You get out of  here quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hit my best friend. Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Martini shove Welch out the door, then run back help George to his feet. George's mouth is cut and bleedi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. Don't worry. His name is  Welch.  He don't come in to my place  no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh В– Welch. That's what I get for  praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time he come in here. You  hear that, Nick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my insurance policy? (finds it in pocket) Oh, here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Please, don't go out this  way, Mr. Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Martini try to stop him, but he shrugs them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no В– you don't feel so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't go away В– please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George opens the door and exits to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's car comes along the empty street, through the fa snow, suddenly swerves and crashes into a tree near the  sidewalk of a house.  George gets out to look at the dama and savagely kicks at the open door of the car, trying to shut it. The noise brings the owner of the house running  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stands unsteadily near the car, shaken by the acci The front lights are broken and the fender is ripped. Geo stands dully looking at the damage. The owner comes up,  looking at his tree. He leans over to examine the damages

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with indignation) Now look what you did. My  greatgrandfather planted this tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George staggers off down the street, paying no attention the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you... Hey, you! Come back here,  you drunken fool! Get this car out  of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is crossing the approach to the bridge when a truc swings around the corner and nearly hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's the matter with you?   Look where you're going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck turns onto the bridge, and George takes a narro catwalk at the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George has stopped by the railing at the center of the br The snow is now falling hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTING DOWN from George's angle TO the water, do with floating ice, passing under the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares down at the water, desperate, trying to make up his mind to act. He leans over looking at the water,  fascinated, glances furtively around him, hunches himself though about to jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above George a body hurtles past and lands in the wa with a loud splash. George looks down, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from river) Help! Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George quickly takes off his coat and dives over the rail into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George comes up, sees the man flailing about in the water and CAMERA PANS WITH him as he swims toward the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help! Help! Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The toll house keeper, hearing the cries for help, comes  running out on the bridge with a flashlight, which he shi on the two figures struggling in the water below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man in the water is Clarence, the angel whose voice w have heard speaking from Heaven. George reaches him, grab hold of him, and starts swimming for shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is seated before a wood-burning stove before which his clothes are drying on a line. He is in his long winte underwear.  He is sipping a mug of hot coffee, staring at the stove, cold, gloomy and drunk, ignoring Clarence and tollkeeper, preoccupied by his near suicide and his unsol problems.  Clarence is standing on the other side of the  stove, putting on his undershirt. This is a ludicrous  seventeenth century garment which looks like a baby's nig shirt В– with embroidered cuffs and collar, and gathered the neck with a drawstring. It falls below his knees.  Th tollkeeper is seated against the wall eyeing them  suspiciously. Throughout the scene he attempts to spit, b each time is stopped by some amazing thing Clarence does says.  Clarence becomes aware that his garment is amazing the tollkeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have time to get some stylish  underwear. My wife gave me this on  my last birthday. I passed away in  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tollkeeper, about to spit, is stopped in the middle o it by this remark. Clarence, secretly trying to get Georg attention, now picks up a copy of "Tom Sawyer" which is  hanging on the line, drying. He shakes the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Tom Sawyer's drying out, too.  You should read the new book Mark  Twain's writing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tollkeeper stares at him incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you happen to fall in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't fall in. I jumped in to  save George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what? To save me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I did, didn't I? You didn't go  through with it, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go through with what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and the tollkeeper react to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's against the law to commit suicide  around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's against the law where I  come from, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans forward to spit, but is stopped by Clarence's ne statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven. (to George) I had to act quickly; that's why I  jumped in. I knew if I were drowning  you'd try to save me. And you see,  you did, and that's how I saved you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tollkeeper becomes increasingly nervous. George casua looks at the strange smiling little man a second time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offhand) Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lip's bleeding, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's hand goes to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got a bust in the jaw in  answer to a prayer a little bit ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comes around to George) Oh, no В– no В– no. I'm the answer to  your prayer. That's why I was sent  down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually interested) How do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know all about you. I've watched  you grow up from a little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, a mind reader or  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who are you, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence Odbody, A-S-2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odbody... A-S-2. What's that A-S-2?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angel, Second Class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tollkeeper's chair slips out from under him with a cr He has been leaning against the wall on it, tipped back o two legs.  Tollkeeper rises and makes his way warily out door. From his expression he looks like he'll call the ne cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to tollkeeper) Cheerio, my good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George rubs his head with his hand, to clear his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, brother. I wonder what Martini  put in those drinks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at Clarence standing beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's with you? What did you  say just a minute ago? Why'd you  want to save me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I was sent down for. I'm  your guardian angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be a bit surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ridiculous of you to think of killing  yourself for money. Eight thousand  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Yeah... just things like that. Now  how'd you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you В– I'm your guardian angel.  I know everything about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you look about like the kind  of an angel I'd get. Sort of a fallen  angel, aren't you? What happened to  your wings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't won my wings yet. That's  why I'm an angel Second Class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether I like it very  much being seen around with an angel  without any wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've got to earn them, and you'll  help me, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (humoring him) Sure, sure. How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By letting me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one way you can help me. You  don't happen to have eight thousand  bucks on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no. We don't use money in  Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's right, I keep forgetting.  Comes in pretty handy down here,  bub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, tut, tut, tut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found it out a little late. I'm  worth more dead than alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, you mustn't talk like that.  I won't get my wings with that  attitude. You just don't know all  that you've done. If it hadn't been  for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Yeah, if it hadn't been for me,  everybody'd be a lot better off. My  wife, and my kids and my friends. (annoyed with Clarence) Look, little fellow, go off and haunt  somebody else, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't understand. I've got  my job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) Aw, shut up, will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence is not getting far with George. He glances up, p across the room, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Hmmm, this isn't going to be so easy. (to George) So you still think killing yourself  would make everyone feel happier,  eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dejectedly) Oh, I don't know. I guess you're  right. I suppose it would have been  better if I'd never been born at  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I wish I'd never been born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mustn't say things like that.   You... (gets an idea) ...wait a minute. Wait a minute.  That's an idea. (glances up toward  Heaven) What do you think? Yeah, that'll do  it.  All right. (to George) You've got your wish. You've never  been born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clarence speaks this line, the snow stops falling outs the building, a strong wind springs up which blows open t door to the shack. Clarence runs to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking upward) You don't have to make all that fuss  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clarence speaks, George cocks his head curiously, favo his deaf ear, more interested in his hearing than in what Clarence has said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never been born. You don't  exist.  You haven't a care in the  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George feels his ear as Clarence talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No worries В– no obligations В– no  eight thousand dollars to get В– no  Potter looking for you with the  Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George indicates his bad ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say something else in that ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bending down) Sure. You can hear out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the doggonedest thing...  I haven't heard anything out of that  ear since I was a kid. Must have  been that jump in the cold water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lip's stopped bleeding, too,  George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George feels his lip, which shows no sign of the recent c he received from Welch. He is now thoroughly confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about that... What's  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks around, as though to  get his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's stopped snowing out, hasn't it?   What's happened here? (standing up) Come on, soon as these clothes of  ours are dry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our clothes are dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George feels the clothes on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about that? Stove's  hotter than I thought. Now, come on,  get your clothes on, and we'll stroll  up to my car and get...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start dressing. George interrupts himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. I'll stroll. You fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't fly. I haven't got any wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got your wings. Yeah,  that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the same empty street where George's car swerved  into the tree near the sidewalk. George and Clarence come into shot and up to the spot where George had left his ca smashed against the tree. George looks around, but his ca is nowhere to be seen, and the tree is undamaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Well, this is where I left my car  and it isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I had a car, and it was right  here.  I guess somebody moved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner of the house passes with some Christmas package under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely) Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, say... Hey... where's my car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My car, my car. I'm the fellow that  owns the car that ran into your tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What tree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, what tree? This  tree.  Here, I ran into it. Cut a  big gash in the side of it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner bends down to examine the trunk of the tree, th straightens up and smells George's breath. He backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must mean two other trees. You  had me worried. One of the oldest  trees in Pottersville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) Pottersville? Why, you mean Bedford  Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean Pottersville. (sharply) Don't you think I know where I live?   What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner proceeds toward his house. George is completely bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Either I'm off my  nut, or he is... (to Clarence) ...or you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I left the car up at  Martini's. Well, come on, Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arm around Clarence, and they start off up th road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go) Clarence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence! Clarence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Martini's place, but almost unrecognizable. The che Italian feeling is gone. It is now more of a hard-drinkin joint, a honky-tonk. Same bar, tables have no covers. Peo are lower down and tougher. Nick the bartender is behind bar. George and Clarence come in. George does not notice difference, but Clarence is all eyes and beaming. They go to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they come in) That's all right. Go on in. Martini's  a good friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two people leave the bar as they approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a place to sit down. Sit  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is wiping off the bar as they  sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Nick. Hey, where's Martini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a martini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, Martini. Your boss. Where is  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Look, I'm the boss. You want a drink  or don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay В– all right. Double bourbon,  quick, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (to Clarence) What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking... (face puckers up with  delicious anticipation) It's been so long since I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Look, mister, I'm standing here  waiting for you to make up your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appreciatively) That's a good man. I was just thinking  of a flaming rum punch. No, it's not  cold enough for that. Not nearly  cold enough...  Wait a minute...  wait a minute... I got it. Mulled  wine, heavy on the cinnamon and light  on the cloves. Off with you, me lad,  and be lively!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look mister, we serve hard drinks  in here for men who want to get drunk  fast.  And we don't need any  characters around to give the joint  atmosphere. Is that clear?  Or do I  have to slip you my left for a  convincer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he says this, Nick leans over the counter and puts his left fist nearly in Clarence's eye. Clarence is puzzled b this conduct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George) What's he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothingly) Nick В– Nick, just give him the same  as mine. He's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick turns away to get the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with him. I never  saw Nick act like that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see a lot of strange things  from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Hey, little fellow В– you  worry me. You got someplace to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't huh? Well, you got any  money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is listening suspiciously to this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder you jumped in the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I jumped in the river to save you so  I could get my wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick stops pouring the drinks, bottle poised in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cash register bell rings off stage. Clarence reacts to SOUND of the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-oh. Somebody's just made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time you hear a bell ring, it  means that some angel's just got his  wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George glances up at Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I think maybe you better not  mention getting your wings around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Don't they believe in angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Nick) A... Yeah, but... you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why should they be surprised  when they see one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nick) He never grew up. He's... (to Clarence) How old are you, anyway, Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred and ninety-three... (thinks) ...next May.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick slams the bottle down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it! Out you two pixies go,  through the door or out the window!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Nick. What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) And that's another thing. Where do  you come off calling me Nick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Nick, that's your name, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with it? I  don't know you from Adam's off ox. (sees someone come in) Hey, you! Rummy! Come here! Come  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small wreck of a man, with weak, watery eyes. Obviously broken-down panhandler, his hat in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can hardly believe his eyes. It is Gower the druggist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gower) Didn't I tell you never to come  panhandling around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick picks up a seltzer bottle, and squirts Gower in the  face with it. The crowd laugh brutally. Gower smiles weak as the soda runs off his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, horrified, leaps up and goes over to Gower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gower! Mr. Gower! This is George  Bailey! Don't you know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his bouncers) Throw him out. Throw him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bouncers throw Gower out the front door. George rushe back to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Hey, what is... Hey, Nick, Nick...  Isn't that Mr. Gower, the druggist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, that's another reason for  me not to like you. That rumhead  spent twenty years in jail for  poisoning a kid. If you know him,  you must be a jailbird yourself. (to his bouncers) Would you show these gentlemen to  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. This way, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Clarence come flying through the door and land the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick at the cash register, busily ringing the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Get me! I'm giving out wings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Clarence lying in the snow. George has a stran puzzled look on his face. They remain for a moment as the landed, looking at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, George, you were not there  to stop Gower from putting that poison  into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, I wasn't there? I  remember distinctly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George catches a glimpse of the front of the building wit the neon sign over the door. It now reads "NICK'S PLACE"  instead of "MARTINI'S." George and Clarence get to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) What the... hey, what's going on  around here?  Why, this ought to be  Martini's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the sign, and looks at Clarence. Clarence so of hangs his head. George fixes him with a very intereste look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) I told you, George. I'm your guardian  angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, still looking at him, goes up to him and pokes hi arm.  It's flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I know. You told me that.  What else are you? What... are you a  hypnotist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, why am I seeing all these  strange things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand, George? It's  because you were not born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then if I wasn't born, who am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're nobody. You have no identity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George rapidly searches his pockets for identification, b without success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, no identity? My  name's George Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no George Bailey. You have  no papers, no cards, no driver's  license, no 4-F card, no insurance  policy... (he says these things  as George searches  for them) George looks in his watch pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not there, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zuzu's petals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George feverishly continues to turn his pockets inside ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been given a great gift,  George. A chance to see what the  world would be like without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is completely befuddled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Now wait a minute, here. Wait a minute  here. As, this is some sort of a  funny dream I'm having here. So long,  mister, I'm going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off. Clarence rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home? What home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Now shut up! Cut it out! You're...   you're... you're crazy! That's what  I think... you're screwy, and you're  driving me crazy, too! I'm seeing  things. I'm going home and see my  wife and family. Do you understand  that? And I'm going home alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George strides off hurriedly. Clarence slowly follows him glancing up toward Heaven as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'm I doing, Joseph. Thanks. (pause) No, I didn't have a drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign bearing the name of the town reads: "Pottersvill George looks at it in surprise, then starts up the street toward the main part of town. As he goes, CAMERA MOVES WI him. The character of the place has completely changed. W before it was a quiet, orderly small town, it has now bec in nature like a frontier village. We see a SERIES OF SHO of night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, pool halls an the like, with blaring jazz MUSIC issuing from the majori of them. The motion picture theatre has become a burlesqu house. Gower's drugstore is now a pawnbroker's establishm and so on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stops before what used to be the offices of the  Building and Loan.  There is a garish electric sign over entrance reading: "Welcome Jitterbugs." A crowd of people are watching the police, who are raiding the place, and  dragging out a number of screaming women, whom they throw into a patrol wagon. George talks to one of the cops:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... hey. Where did the Building  and Loan move to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Building and what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bailey Building and Loan. It was  up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They went out of business years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sees the struggling figure of Violet Bick, arrayed a tart, being dragged into the patrol wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Violet! (to the cop) Hey, listen В– that's Violet Bick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop shoves George to one side. He looks around and se Ernie's taxi cruising slowly by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ernie В– Ernie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie stops the cab, and George enters it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie, take me home. I'm off my nut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a much harder Ernie) Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, now, doggone it, Ernie, don't  you start pulling that stuff. You  know where I live. Three-twenty  Sycamore. Now hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Three-twenty Sycamore?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah В– yeah В– hurry up. Zuzu's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  He pulls down the flag  on the meter and starts the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie is puzzled by the stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here, Ernie, straighten me out  here.  I've got some bad liquor or  something.  Listen to me now. Now,  you are Ernie Bishop, and you live  in Bailey Park with your wife and  kid? That's right, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) You seen my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Seen your wife? I've been to your  house a hundred times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, bud, what's the idea?  I live  in a shack in Potter's Field and my  wife ran away three years ago and  took the kid...  And I ain't never  seen you before in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Just step on it. Just get me  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie turns to driving, but he's worried about his passen As he passes the burlesque house he sees Bert the cop sta beside his police car. Attracting his attention, he motio to Bert to follow him, indicating he has a nut in the bac Bert gets into his car and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls up to the curb and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab is parked. George gets out and looks at the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this house ain't been lived in  for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is stopped momentarily by the appearance of the ho Windows are broken, the porch sags, one section of the ro has fallen, doors and shutters hang askew on their hinges Like a doomed man, George approaches the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car has pulled up beside the cab, and Bert and Ernie stand watching George's actions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, Ernie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but we better keep an  eye on this guy. He's bats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie switches on the spotlight on his cab, and turns the beam toward the old house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the house is lit up here and there, ghost by Ernie's spotlight. No furniture, cobwebs, wallpaper ha and swinging В– stairs are broken and collapsed. In a voi that sounds like a cry for help, George yells out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary! Mary! Tommy! Pete! Janie! Zuzu!   Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence suddenly appears leaning against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not here, George. You have  no children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) Where are you? (then, to Clarence) What have you done with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert is standing in the entrance, with his gun in his han Ernie is a few feet behind him, ready to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, put up your hands. No  fast moves. Come on out here, both  of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert! Thank heaven you're here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes toward Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, what's happened to this house?   Where's Mary? Where's my kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warningly) Watch him, Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Bert В– Ernie! What's the matter with  you two guys? You were here on my  wedding night. You, both of you,  stood out here on the porch and sung  to us, don't you remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Think I'd better be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, now why don't you be a good  kid and we'll take you in to a doctor.   Everything's going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert tries to lead George away by the arm, but George  struggles with him, trying to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, now listen to me. Ernie, will  you take me over to my mother's house?  Bert, listen! (gesturing to Clarence) It's that fellow there В– he says  he's an angel В– he's tried to  hypnotize me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to do this, fella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert raises his gun to hit George on the head. As he does so, Clarence darts in and fixes his teeth in Bert's wrist forcing him to let George go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run... George! Run, George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George dashes out of the house and down the street, as Be grapples with Clarence, and they fall to the ground,  wrestling. We see Bert kneeling, trying to put handcuffs Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help! Joseph, help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help, oh Joseph, help! Joseph!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Clarence disappears from under Bert's hands. Ber gets up, amazed by his vanishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd he go? Where'd he go? I had  him right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie's hair is now standing on end with fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stammering) I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, which way'd they go? Help me  find 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George runs up the path to the front door of the house an raps on the door. He rings the bell and taps on the glass when his attention is caught by a sign on the wall readin "Ma Bailey's Boarding House."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and a woman appears. It is Mrs. Bailey, bu she has changed amazingly. Her face is harsh and tired. I her eyes, once kindly and understanding, there is now col suspicion. She gives no sign that she knows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a cruel blow to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, this is George. I thought  sure you'd remember me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) George who? If you're looking for a  room there's no vacancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to close the door, but George stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mother, Mother, please help me.   Something terrible's happened to me.  I don't know what it is. Something's  happened to everybody. Please let me  come in. Keep me here until I get  over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get over what? I don't take in  strangers unless they're sent here  by somebody I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) Well, I know everybody you know.  Your brother-in-law, Uncle Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When'd you see him last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, over at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie. He's been in the insane  asylum ever since he lost his  business.  And if you ask me, that's  where you belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slams the door shut in George's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stands a moment, stunned. Then he turns and runs o to the sidewalk, until his face fills the screen. His fea are distorted by the emotional chaos within him. We see  Clarence leaning on the mail box at the curb, holding his volume of "Tom Sawyer" in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange, isn't it?  Each man's life  touches so many other lives, and  when he isn't around he leaves an  awful hole, doesn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, trying to  use logic) I've heard of things like this. You've  got me in some kind of a spell, or  something.  Well, I'm going to get  out of it. I'll get out of it. I  know how, too. I... the last man I  talked to before all this stuff  started happening to me was Martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where he lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I know where he lives. He lives  in Bailey Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Clarence approach the tree from which the "Bai Park" sign once hung. Now it is just outside a cemetery,  with graves where the houses used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is Bailey Park?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not sure of anything anymore.  All I know is this should be Bailey  Park. But where are the houses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two walk into the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go) You weren't here to build them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George wandering like a lost soul among the tombstones,  Clarence trotting at his heels. Again George stops to sta with frightened eyes at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon it is engraved a name, Harry Bailey. Feverishly Geor scrapes away the snow covering the rest of the inscriptio and we read: "IN MEMORY OF OUR BELOVED SON В– HARRY BAILE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother, Harry Bailey, broke  through the ice and was drowned at  the age of nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie! Harry Bailey went to  war! He got the Congressional Medal  of Honor! He saved the lives of every  man on that transport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) Every man on that transport died.  Harry wasn't there to save them  because you weren't there to save  Harry. You see, George, you really  had a wonderful life.  Don't you see  what a mistake it would be to throw  it away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you know these  things, but tell me В– where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George grabs Clarence by the coat collar and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you know where she is, tell me  where my wife is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (becoming violent) Please, Clarence, tell me where she  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to like it, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's an old maid. She never married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking him) Where's Mary? Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in self-defense) She's just about to close up the  library!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George lets Clarence go, and runs off. Clarence falls to ground, where he rubs his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) There must be some easier way for me  to get my wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes out the door, then turns and locks it. We see  George watching her from the sidewalk. Mary is very diffe В– no buoyancy in her walk, none of Mary's abandon and lo of life.  Glasses, no make-up, lips compressed, elbows cl to body. She looks flat and dried up, and extremely self- satisfied and efficient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, as he watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Mary, on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up, surprised, but, not recognizing him, contin on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts to run away from him, and he follows, despera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary! Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He catches up to her, grabs her by the arms, and keeps a  tight grip on her. She struggles to free herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, it's George! Don't you know  me?  What's happened to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling) I don't know you! Let me go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, please! Oh, don't do this to  me.  Please, Mary, help me. Where's  our kids? I need you, Mary! Help me,  Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary breaks away from him, and dashes into the first door she comes to, the Blue Moon Bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small tables, booths, perhaps a counter. It is crowded. M of the people are the same who were present during the ru on the Building and Loan. Mary comes running in, screamin The place goes into an uproar. George comes in, practical insane. Some of the men grab and hold on to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Mary... (to men holding him) Let me go! Mary, don't run away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody call the police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit him with a bottle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs a strait jacket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from back of room) That man В– stop him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing some of  them) Tom! Ed! Charlie! That's my wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary lets out a final scream, then faints into the arms o couple of women at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no you don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George can't fight through the men holding him. Desperate he thinks of Clarence, and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence! Clarence! Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as George breaks through the door, Bert arrives in h police car. He gets out and heads for the door, to run in George as he comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs for George, who lets him have one square on the  button, knocking him down, then continues running down th street yelling for Clarence. Bert gets up, takes out his and fires several shots after the fleeing figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to crowd) Stand back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert gets into the police car, and, siren screaming, sets off in pursuit of George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same part of the bridge where George was standing bef Clarence jumped in. The wind is blowing as it has all thr this sequence. George comes running into shot. He is  frantically looking for Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence! Clarence! Help me, Clarence.  Get me back. Get me back. I don't  care what happens to me. Only get me  back to my wife and kids. Help me,  Clarence, please!  Please! I want to  live again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George leaning on the bridge railing, praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to live again. I want to live  again. Please, God, let me live again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sobs. Suddenly, toward the end of the above, the w dies down. A soft, gentle snow begins to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car pulls up on the roadway behind him, and Be comes into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, George! George! You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George backs away and gets set to hit Bert again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warningly) Now get out of here, Bert, or I'll  hit you again! Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the Sam Hill you yelling for,  George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't... George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George talks hopefully В– George touches Bert unbelieving George's mouth is bleeding again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, do you know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know you? Are you kiddin'? I've been  looking all over town trying to find  you.  I saw your car piled into that  tree down there, and I thought  maybe... Hey, your mouth's bleeding;  are you sure you're all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did...
